DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Jet Knocks Cessna's Baggage Compartment Off at 4,000 Feet
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard jet collided with a small plane 4,000 feet above the Bahamas on Saturday, knocking the twin-engine Cessna's baggage compartment into the surf, but causing no injuries, authorities said. The Falcon jet was flying at about 4,000 feet on a routine law enforcement patrol over Bimini island on Saturday morning when its tail struck the Cessna's baggage compartment, said Lt. Jeff Karonis, a Coast Guard spokesman in Miami. The Cessna carried a pilot and five San Francisco science teachers. ``Considering the impact and everything, everybody involved was very lucky, said aircraft mechanic Bill Peck, who examined the Cessna after it safely landed in Miami. ``If there had been about five or 10 inches difference in the way the jet had hit the bottom of the plane, the people on the plane definitely would have been killed.'' The belly of the Cessna was scraped where its baggage compartment was ripped off and about six inches of the jet's upper tail section broke off, officials said. The Federal Aviation Administration was investigating the incident, Karonis said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: `Clock Is Ticking' Toward War With Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney warned Sunday that ``the clock is ticking'' quickly toward war with Iraq. Cheney also appeared to indirectly confirm that U.S. forces, known to have nuclear weapons aboard naval vessels, also have some chemical weapons capacity in the Persian Gulf region. The secretary is wrapping up a five-day visit to Saudi Arabia that included classified strategy sessions with commanders and two days of pre-Christmas troop visits. As he had all week, Cheney ducked questions about whether the United States has decided on a timetable to attack Iraq if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ignores a United Nations-imposed Jan. 15 deadline to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq overran the neighboring emirate on Aug. 2 and later annexed it. ``The clock is ticking as each day goes by and he (Saddam) does not withdraw his forces from Kuwait,'' Cheney said. He told reporters that the American troop deployment in the region was nearing the 300,000 mark. Cheney refused to answer when asked directly if the United States has chemical weapons in the region. But he referred a reporter back to his answer to an earlier question, when he said President Bush had available a ``full spectrum'' of weapons should he decide to order an attack. On another matter, Cheney said he did not believe it was necessary for American dependents to leave the Saudi Arabian province bordering Kuwait. Britain has recommended that its citizens leave Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province by the U.N. deadline. But Cheney said, ``I don't believe it's unsafe for people who are here in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia.''

Churches: Stop Attempts To Intervene In Nancy Cruzan Case
DOC.TEXT: Religious leaders urged prayers for Nancy Cruzan and her family Saturday and called on anti-euthanasia groups to stop trying to force the state to resume feeding the woman, who is in a vegetative state. Her father, Joe Cruzan, said Saturday that those protesting on his daughter's behalf don't understand that if she could express herself she would say she does not want to live. Mark Roebuck, a spokesman for the Missouri Department of Health, said late Saturday that Ms. Cruzan's condition continues to deteriorate and will soon be downgraded to critical. She has been in a persistent vegetative state since she was injured in a car accident almost eight years ago. Doctors predicted Ms. Cruzan, 33, would die within two weeks after her feeding tube was removed Dec. 14. Her father told The Joplin Globe that terminal cancer patients in the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, where Ms. Cruzan is a patient, have rejected food and not been force-fed. ``We believe that Nancy would reject this treatment if she were able to make a decision,'' he said. ``She can't, so therefore we have to make it for her.'' Anti-euthanasia activists were stymied last week in asking various courts to force the state to resume feeding Ms. Cruzan. Those legal setbacks, snow and bitterly cold weather have lowered morale among some 15 demonstrators camped outside the Missouri Rehabilitation Center where Ms. Cruzan is cared for. But spokesman Andrew Burnett said, ``They're planning on keeping the vigil up to the end of this ordeal. Spokesman Andrew Burnett, director of the anti-abortion and anti-euthanasia group Advocates for Life, said the protesters were ``planning on keeping the vigil up to the end of this ordeal.'' In the meantime, the Rev. Patrick J. Mahoney, a Protestant minister who runs the Center for Christian Activism in Boca Raton, Fla., an advocacy group, appealed Saturday to the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis to get Ms. Cruzan's tube reconnected. In his appeal, Mahoney asked the court to order the feeding tube reconnected until it can determine whether Ms. Cruzan's civil rights were violated. ``In essence, Ms. Cruzan has been given a `death sentence' without process of the law,'' the appeal document said. The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, the United Methodist Church, the Presbyterian Church (USA) and the Unitarian Universalist Association of Congregations joined in issuing a statement supporting Joe and Joyce Cruzan and their other two daughters, Donna and Christy. The Cruzans are Methodists. ``We urge that those who are attempting to disrupt the ruling of the court and the wishes of Nancy Cruzan and her family end their activities and join us in respecting the judgments of the courts, which have thoroughly examined the questions involved in the Cruzan case and have concurred in the Cruzan family's decision,'' the statement said. The statement also asked Americans to ``lend their prayerful support to the family of Nancy Beth Cruzan as they face the most difficult days of their life.'' Demonstrations at the rehabilitation center and the 19 arrests there Tuesday only further burdened the Cruzans, said Kay Dowhower, director of the Evangelical Lutheran Church offices in Washington. ``We would hope our statement would be a sign of support and appreciation for how lonely death and the death process can be,'' Mrs. Dowhower said. ``God and nature should take its own course. What we have done in this case is prolong the suffering by sustaining life.'' The Roman Catholic Church also expressed support for the Cruzans. In a letter to be published Sunday in The News-Leader in Springfield, Bishop John J. Leibrecht of the Springfield-Cape Girardeau Diocese said removing Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube was ``morally permissible.'' Fourteen demonstrators remained jailed Saturday, still invoking the name Nancy Cruzan and refusing to eat until she is fed or dies. On Friday, Joe Cruzan presented demonstrators huddled outside the hospital in 15-degree weather with a new coffee maker, filters, cups and an extension cord. ``We are doing what we feel God has directed us to do, and that is to carry out what we believe,'' he told them. ``We believe we are in the best position to know what would be Nancy's wishes.'' Cruzan said he appreciated their prayers and hoped the ordeal would be over soon. ``Let's all pray for a miracle that God will put an end to this and raise her up out of that bed and we can all go home and have a merry Christmas,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed, 50 Injured In Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through part of a nine-story apartment building early Sunday, killing at least six people and injuring 50, including 12 firemen, officials said. Thirty-nine of the injured were hospitalized, and at least five were seriously hurt, fire officials said. Officials said the fire, which burned for three hours, started in a second floor apartment of the building in the Shum Shui Po district of Hong Kong. The dead included five men but the sixth victim was burned beyond recognition, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll In Capsizing Raised To 21
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Navy raising death toll to 21, memorial service; ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in the sinking of a charter ferry carrying American sailors was raised to 21 Sunday and included one man whose body had not been recovered, a U.S. Navy official said. The body of the 20th victim was recovered by Israeli divers earlier Sunday, Haifa police said. Neither of the latest two victims was identified. The ferry capsized Saturday shortly after midnight as it was carrying 102 American seamen to the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga from a Christmas shore leave. Capt. Joseph S. Mobley, the Saratoga's skipper, told reporters Sunday about the higher death toll after a tearful memorial service aboard the carrier. ``It is 21 lives lost. We still have the man whom we have not recovered. We have the utmost confidence that he did perish,'' Mobley said. About 1,200 crewmen of the Saratoga, including the 81 survivors of the accident, attended the memorial service in a hangar aboard the carrier. Two sailors dropped a wreathe into the metallic gray water from a hangar bay door in front of the mourners. A detachment of Marines fired three rifle salvos into the cloudy, darkening sky. Some of the survivors wiped tears from their eyes as a choir sang ``America'' and the Navy hymn, ``Eternal Father.'' The Saratoga and its three escort ships were in the Red Sea as part of the naval buildup in the Persian Gulf region following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The accident was the deadliest involving U.S. servicemen in Operation Desert Shield, and it raised the number of Americans who have died to at least 74.

DOC.HEAD: Sadness Tinges Christmas for Ryan White's Mother
DOC.TEXT: Preserving the Christmas tradition of a cozy house festooned with decorations, family pictures and love is even more important to Jeanne White since her son, Ryan, died from AIDS last spring. ``When you face a crisis like we have, the family is the one that pulls together and stays together. You cannot do it without family,'' Mrs. White said. The holiday decorations almost didn't come out this year. But Mrs. White ultimately decided to follow the tradition Ryan loved. ``Even though I'm sad a lot, especially this holiday season has really been rough, I feel like he's just everywhere. He's in every part of everything I do,'' Mrs. White said. It helps that her mother is staying with her this month, and her sister's family will be in for Christmas Day. Plus, the phone continually rings with friends from around the country, charities seeking Mrs. White's endorsement and reporters wanting interviews. The chaos is a kind of therapy for Mrs. White, who has taken another one-year leave from her assembly line job at General Motors Corp.'s Delco plant in Kokomo. ``I don't know whether there'll be a time when I'm tired of talking about AIDS. ... We keep losing so many friends to it, the people we have met along the way,'' she said. ``It drains you and you wonder, out of a lot of the people we met, when are they going to come down with it?'' Ryan died April 8 at age 18 after a five-year battle with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. A hemophiliac, he was 13 when diagnosed with AIDS that he contracted through a tainted blood product. Hatred and abuse were heaped on Ryan and his family by Kokomo residents, who fought to keep Ryan out of middle school. He won a landmark court case to attend school but the family left the school district anyway, moving to the quiet lakeside home in Cicero, about 20 miles north of Indianapolis. At that school, he was welcomed and befriended. Recently, a group of musicians released a song, ``Colors,'' as a tribute to Ryan's memory and to promote AIDS awareness. Next up: a book started by Ryan that chronicles his life and deals frankly with questions about AIDS. A co-author helped Mrs. White finish the book after his death. ``Ryan White: My Own Story,'' is scheduled for release March 15 by Dial Books, with proceeds going to the Ryan White Fund at Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis. A spring tribute to Ryan is planned in Los Angeles to benefit the charities who supported him. Amid her grief, the 42-year-old Mrs. White remains focused on the killer disease that took her son away. ``It's on my mind a lot. I see more and more hemophiliacs who are dying or who are coming down with AIDS, and it's like, do I want to continue to be around all this tragedy?'' She answers her own question. ``You want to motivate some goodness. There are some things I want to see get done,'' she said. ``I want to generate more awareness to where everybody understands this disease and to make it a disease like cancer, or anything else, that people can talk about. A disease that maybe we can have some hope for ... where the end result isn't always death.''

DOC.HEAD: Archaeologists Discover Ancient Etruscan Sculptures
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists have discovered an Etruscan tomb with unusual statues that could shed new light on the empire that dominated Italy before succumbing to the Roman Empire, news reports said. The tomb, near Cortona in central Italy, is believed to date to the sixth or seventh century B.C. It was discovered last week, the reports said Saturday. The regional archaeological superintendent, Francesco Nicosia, told the Italian news agency ANSA that the discovery was of ``unimagined dimensions.'' The tomb has seven rooms and is flanked by a terrace with steps decorated with two statues. One shows a sphinx fighting with a warrior, and the other depicts a sphinx crushing a man. They are the only such Etruscan statues known to exist, and could shed new light on the Etruscans' contacts with other peoples, news reports said. The Etruscans were known for commercial flair, an elaborate religion and a brilliant artisan tradition. Etruscan culture flourished until the 1st century B.C.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Car Explodes, Killing Seven People
DOC.TEXT: A railway tanker car loaded with liquid natural gas exploded near two passenger trains in central Russia, killing seven people and injuring 48 others, Tass reported Sunday. The force of the explosion blew the locomotive from one passenger train into the path of a second oncoming passenger train, the official Soviet news agency said. Carriages on both trains caught fire and 16 were destroyed, Tass said. Tass said the tanker car was sitting on a railway siding when it exploded at Yelnikovo Station near Belgorod in south-central Russia. A ``powerful blast wave'' struck a passenger train sitting on an adjacent track, and threw its locomotive onto a third track into the path of the oncoming train, it said. All those killed were passengers on the stationery train, which had been en route from the Black Sea port of Kislovodsk to Leningrad, Tass said. The oncoming passenger train was traveling southeast from Moscow to Kharkov in the Ukraine.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Papers Won't Be Available for Years
DOC.TEXT: The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library is nearing completion on a California hilltop, but it may be years before the former president's papers are available to scholars. Reagan is the first president to come under a 1978 law that makes presidential papers the property of the government and gives the National Archives five years to process them. ``We would prefer to use the full five years for processing,'' John T. Fawcett, assistant archivist for presidential libraries, said in an interview. However, some papers may be available before the expiration of the five years, which would be Jan. 20, 1994, Fawcett said. The law also requires the agency to ``make such records available to the public as rapidly and completely as possible.'' ``Most former presidents tend to want to open these papers rather quickly,'' the Archives official said. ``There are good administrative reasons why we should wait five years to begin opening the papers, but we may do it sooner.'' Cathy Goldberg, a spokeswoman for Reagan, said from Los Angeles that Reagan ``is pleased that scholars, students and the public will have access to the presidential papers of his administration, but since the library is under construction at this time, the date of availability has not been determined.'' Samuel Gammon, executive director of the American Historical Association, said, ``In general, we are always anxious to see things as soon as possible, but we do recognize that the National Archives, in handling presidential libraries, has certain financial problems and so on.'' Until Reagan, former presidents owned their White House papers, except for those of Richard Nixon, which were made government property b special legislation after the Watergate scandals. Since the establishment of the presidential library system, beginning with the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library in Hyde Park, N.Y., other presidents have donated their papers to the government and they have generally been available in less than five years. Reagan's library, being built near Simi Valley, Calif., is expected to be completed shortly after his 80th birthday on Feb. 6. After that, the Archives will begin moving in the papers, which are now stored in a warehouse in Culver City, Calif. Then the Ronald Reagan Foundation will install museum exhibits dealing with the careers of Reagan and his wife, Nancy. Dedication of the library is scheduled for early November. Reagan, the first president to serve eight years since Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1950's, left behind a record amount of paper, an estimated 52,600 cubic feet. Fawcett said more than 20,000 cubic feet or 40 million pages, almost equal to the entire bulk of the Nixon papers, were destroyed in a program initiated by the Archives. These papers were part of the mail to the president from members of the public. Fawcett said a sample was kept, along with careful records of the rest. These were the only Reagan papers destroyed, he said. The documents had to be transported farther than any other presidential papers had, since Reagan is from California. So, for the first time, the papers were flown. Fawcett said the Archives considered using trucks or trains, or even barging the documents through the Panama Canal, but concluded that flying them would cost about the same as truck transportation and be safer and quicker. A staff of 14 has been processing the papers at Culver City. The library will have a staff of 22. Under the law, the former president's personal papers, those not related to official business, remain his own property. This category includes papers dealing with his 1984 re-election campaign. But Fawcett said Reagan, like Jimmy Carter before him, has decided to deed campaign papers to the government. Both Reagan and then Vice President George Bush exercised an option in the law to shield several categories of papers from public scrutiny for up to 12 years. These include classified national security matters, information about appointments to federal offices, trade secrets, confidential advice of presidential advisers, information infringing on personal privacy and information that is protected by other laws. Archives is deciding what papers fit into each category. If a researcher challenges such a classification, Archives must justify its decision within 30 days. Fawcett said archivists will make recommendations to Reagan's representative, Los Angeles attorney Stephen Blitz, to open up some of these papers in less than 12 years. For instance, he said, there may often be no longer any reason to keep advice to the president on past decisions confidential. Blitz' office said he was out of town and not available. Bush's vice presidential papers are stored at the Archives in Washington and may become part of his presidential library, Fawcett said. Rice University in Houston, the University of Houston and Texas A & M have all bid to be the site of that library. However long it takes for Reagan's papers to become public, it is certain to be sooner than before the advent of presidential libraries. Abraham Lincoln's papers were not open to public research until 1949, and the Adams family still imposes some restrictions on the papers of John and John Quincy Adams, Fawcett said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Blacks Killed In Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Five blacks died from gunshot wounds in the troubled eastern province of Natal and a policeman was fatally shot in a black township outside Johannesburg, police reported Sunday. The policeman was standing guard outside a residential block for women in the Alexandra township when unidentified gunmen fired on the officer, police said. In Natal, a policeman fatally shot a black man and wounded another when he came under attack by an unidentified group outside Pietermaritzburg, the provincial capital. Also, police found the bullet-riddled bodies of two men and a woman in Kwamakuta, near the port city of Durban. Another man who died of gunshot wounds was found at Dongonya, about 18 miles south of Durban. The daily police unrest report, which covers incidents from the previous 24 hours, gave no additional details on the incidents. More than 3,000 South African blacks have died in unrest during 1990, the worst year on record. Most of the deaths have occurred in faction fighting between rival black political groups. But more than 200 blacks have been killed in clashes with the security forces.

DOC.HEAD: Year Ends On Bleak Note, Grim Prospects For Future
DOC.TEXT: Next year in the Philippines probably will be a grim one of rising inflation, a declining economy and political instability. After three years of economic growth rates over 5 percent, many economists predict recession in 1991, with sharp increases in unemployment, especially if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. Higher oil costs that followed Iraq's seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 forced the government to raise consumer fuel prices by more than 45 percent. That sent shock waves through an economy already struggling with double-digit inflation, and there are clear signs the business community is losing confidence in President Corazon Aquino. The Philippines gets 64 percent of its energy from imported oil and more than 80 percent of it comes from the Middle East. New foreign investments declined by 47 percent in the first eight months of 1990 and the departure of capital rose 342 percent as financiers moved their money to more stable havens. ``We have not only lost our sense of bearings, we have taken leave of our senses,'' Teodoro Benigno, Mrs. Aquino's former spokesman, wrote in the Philippine Star. ``The Philippines is now looked upon abroad as a basket case.'' Annual inflation of about 12 percent, is expected to reach 16 percent even without war in the gulf. That will lead to demands by labor for wage increases industry says it cannot afford. ``Strikes and demonstrations are going to abound in the months ahead,'' Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. of Hong Kong said in a report last month. ``The government is widely perceived as being helpless.'' Aurelio Periquet, president of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said industrial output could decline 40 percent in 1991 because of higher fuel costs and a chronic energy shortage. Labor Secretary Ruben Torres said recently that unemployment in this nation of 60 million people may rise to 13 percent from the current level of 9 percent. Thousands of Filipinos have fled jobs in Iraq and Kuwait, not only adding to the unemployment rolls but reducing remittances, a major source of hard currency. A national election scheduled for 1992, with no clear successor to Mrs. Aquino in sight, virtually guarantees political uncertainty. The president has said she will not seek a second term. Mutinous soldiers, after seven uprisings against Mrs. Aquino, say they will try at least once more to overthrow her. Communist rebels remain active, but their strength has declined because of ideological differences and failures in strategy. Mrs. Aquino says her government's economic strategy was derailed by the Persian Gulf and an earthquake in July that killed nearly 1,700 people. Critics blame the looming economic crisis on government indecision and mismanagement. Fearful of domestic unrest, the Aquino government stalled for nearly 18 months on a pledge to the International Monetary Fund to reduce the budget deficit by eliminating subsidies on prices of petroleum products. The deficit grew to 60 billion pesos ($2.1 billion), more than three times the original estimate, causing the IMF to delay new loans and aid. On Dec. 5, the government raised fuel prices 45 percent, more than the increase for crude oil. That plunged Mrs. Aquino's administration into a political crisis marked by nationwide transport strikes and calls for her resignation. Foreign exchange has become so scarce, industrialist Raul Concepcion declared in a recent speech, that even if oil fell to $20 a barrel, the Philippines still would not have the dollars to pay. ``Our exports, at $8 billion, will be flat,'' he said. ``People do not seem to be aware of the gravity of the crisis and the government seems reluctant to open up.'' Despite the problems, the public appears tired of politics after years of political upheaval. Demonstrations against oil price increases have been minuscule compared with the ``people power'' uprising of 1986 that drove the late President Ferdinand Marcos into exile and propelled Mrs. Aquino to power. Jose Luis Alcuaz, a former government telecommunications chief who organized recent protests of oil prices, said people have been numbed by a series of problems. ``It's really difficult to organize now. It will take some time.'' That may explain, in part, why no clear successor to Mrs. Aquino has emerged. National elections are scheduled for May 1992. Among possible candidates mentioned are House Speaker Ramon Mitra, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos, Senate President Jovito Salonga, businessman Eduardo Cojuangco and former the former immigration chief, Miriam Defensor-Santiago. None seems to have generated public enthusiasm. Many Filipinos believe the structure Mrs. Aquino set up early in her administration is too unwieldy to work, regardless of who is president. In 1986, she re-established a U.S.-style bicameral legislature and presided over the writing of a new constitution modeled after the American system of checks and balances. Without strong executive leadership, the system proved sluggish and decisions come only after long, painful processes of compromise.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Has Military's Map Makers Working at Wartime Levels
DOC.TEXT: Operating at a wartime pace, the U.S. Defense Mapping Agency says it has shipped 35 million maps to the nearly 300,000 U.S. troops stationed in the Persian Gulf. That may seem like overkill. But the military needs maps of varying detail and intricacy, with many to be used once and discarded, the agency says. ``We certainly hope it doesn't come to war, but if it were to become a hostile action, we want our troops to have the best products they can,'' said Dave Black, the agency's director of public affairs. ``When the Joint Chiefs of Staff lay out the requirements, we meet them.'' Cartographers at the agency's two major production centers in St. Louis and Brookmont, Md., have been working 10- to 12-hour shifts, seven days a week, since shortly after the United States began sending troops to the Persian Gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield. They worked around the clock through Labor Day and Thanksgiving, and there might not be any extra time at home for Christmas - not with a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait or face possible military action. All of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq have been committed to paper, Black said. The agency has had every country in the volatile Middle East mapped for several years, relying heavily on detailed satellite photos. About 4,500 different maps have been used in the territory covered by Operation Desert Shield, breaking down the topography into relatively small coverage areas for pilots, tank commanders, admirals and ground troops. Generally, pilots need the big picture. But pilots of low-flying aircraft - including helicopters and jets launched from aircraft carriers - need more specific information about hills and other terrain than bomber pilots. Soldiers on the ground need to know where roads and power lines are. The number of maps shipped to the gulf include countless spares. Pilots might mark out a mission on a map, then discard it. Ground troops do likewise for another reason. ``You've got these things folded up and stuffed in your pocket, so after a sweaty day in the desert they literally come apart,'' said A. Clay Ancell, deputy director in charge of production at the center in St. Louis, where aeronautical maps are made. Maps for land and sea are produced at Brookmont, near Washington, D.C. Nearly every soldier in the desert has some sort of map. The first ones began arriving in Saudi Arabia about a week after the first U.S. troops landed there. Thanks to improved technology, map production has already overstepped what was done during the Korean and Vietnam wars. ``During the Korean War, the presses ran 24 hours a day, seven days a week for years,'' said Otto Stoessel, graphic arts chief of the aerospace division. ``We turned out a lot of work, but compared to Operation Desert Shield it was nothing. ``We've done 10 times the amount of work in the last two months than we did during all of Korea,'' he said. The Defense Mapping Agency has been in existence since 1972. Before that, each branch of the service took care of its own requirements, which often caused duplication. About 8,000 people are employed at the centers in St. Louis and Brookmont, and even before the Persian Gulf crisis they were busy, said Ancell. Maps constantly must be updated, and before last August the agency also was busy making maps used in the nation's battle to stop the flow of drugs from South America. ``We're always playing catch-up,'' Ancell said. ``If you would gather up the Joint Chiefs of Staff, none of them would be happy with the support that their command receives. They always want more.''

DOC.HEAD: Christian Groups Divided on Columbus Celebration
DOC.TEXT: As much of the nation prepares to commemorate Jesus Christ's birth, Christian groups have split on whether the arrival of their faith in the Americas 500 years ago should be celebrated or mourned. The Roman Catholic Church plans a warts-and-all celebration of five centuries of Christianity for its 55 million members. The National Council of Churches is planning counterdemonstrations to protest Christian churches' complicity in ``the perpetuation of paternalism and racism into our cultures and times.'' The council says Christians should tear asunder what Christopher Columbus has wrought in terms of the exploitation of native populations. The group's document has some historians accusing the council of reviving ``the black legend'' used to condemn Roman Catholic expansion into the New World during the Reformation. The bloody 16th century religious movement was aimed at reforming the Catholic Church and resulted in the establishment of Protestantism. ``The rationale is that it needs to be a year of repentance and reflection, rather than a year of celebration,'' said the Rev. Joe Agne, a leader of the racial justice group that developed the council of churches' statement. The Catholic Church and some other religious groups say the injustices caused by colonization need to be recognized, but so should the good the faith has done in this part of the world. ``I'm kind of sorry for those who call themselves Christians who don't think it's something to celebrate,'' said the Rev. James Hennessey, a priest and historian at Canisius College. The national council, which includes most of the mainline Protestant churches, states what ``some historians have termed a `discovery' in reality was an invasion and colonization with legalized occupation, genocide, economic exploitation and a deep level of institutional racism and moral decadence.'' Other groups such as Clergy and Laity Concerned, an interfaith group with 20,000 members, also have said there is little to celebrate. ``I would have to say that although Christianity is a great thing, the Christian church, as a human institution, has been responsible for some pretty immense wrongdoing over the years,'' said Mark Reeve, editor of the CALC Report. Others, though, accentuate the positive. Said Catholic Archbishop Edward McCarthy of Miami: ``Already, strong forces have gathered to characterize Chritianity in the ugliest of terms while the reality of the church's commitment to the Americas is unparalleled in the annals of human history.'' A pastoral letter approved by the Catholic bishops in November - ``Heritage and Hope: Evangelization in America'' - apologizes for the racism and mistreatment native populations have endured since Columbus landed. But they added: ``Over the centuries, thousands of men and women sought to bring the good news of Jesus Christ to their times, healing the sick, educating the ignorant and witnessing to their culture of the presence of Christ.'' Rabbi James Rudin, director of interreligious affairs for the American Jewish Committee, agreed that, on balance, there's much to celebrate in 1992. Although 1492 - the year Jewish people were expelled from Spain - was a dark moment in Jewish history, the voyage of Columbus paved the way for ``one of the greatest Jewish communities in history,'' the one in the United States, he said. ``From a Jewish perspective, the arrival of Columbus is looked on with great favor ... because it opened up a new era in Jewish life,'' Rudin said. Some historians say the National Council of Churches document almost revives the stereotype of the passive ``noble savage'' in presenting history in stark contrasts of good and evil. They point out, contrary to the council of churches document, some Indian groups at the time engaged in slavery and inhuman practices such as blood sacrifices. ``I see a reverse kind of racism in that nothing good can come from the people of Europe and only good can come from the people called primitive,'' said historian Martin Marty of the University of Chicago. Other historians also questioned why the document dwelled on the evils of Catholic missionary efforts, and failed to specifically criticize the effects of English colonization or other largely Protestant efforts in displacing native populations. ``You pick on the Spanish because that was part of the Reformation polemic. The Spanish made good bad guys from the point of view of Anglo-Saxon tradition,'' said historian James Muldoon of Rutgers University. ``This is a throwback to the 16th century Reformation polemic.'' The Rev. Sam Wynn, head of the Native American International Caucus of the United Methodist Church, said there's enough blame to go around. For example, he said, a United Methodist district superintendent led a cavalry massacre of 700 people. ``This is not a time to celebrate past events that have annhilated whole groups of people in the name of God,'' he said. But others point out that even dating back to the days of Columbus, Christian groups were outspoken in raising moral concerns over issues such as racism and the treatment of native peoples. ``Maybe the way we examine ourselves today is due to the consciousness raising that has occurred in the past 500 years,'' said Maria Luisa Gaston, coordinator of the Catholic celebration.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Doesn't Provide Food or Fuel for Winter
LaserPhoto SOF3
DOC.TEXT: Romanians and Bulgarians, whose farms once fed Eastern Europe, welcome freedom after decades of oppression but are more occupied with the struggle to get enough food and fuel for the winter. They had hoped economic hard times would end with the downfall of their the old regimes a year ago, but it hasn't happened. ``We need food and clothes,'' said Livia Hosszu of Timisoara. ``You can't eat democracy.'' In Romania, food production has declined 20 percent since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed. Less is being exported, but much finds its way to the high-priced black market. Only 120 tons of meat were left in Bulgaria's main warehouse by mid-December. Sofia alone normally needs 7,000 tons a month. Sugar, cooking oil and potatoes also were scarce or unavailable and energy was rationed. After Ceausescu and Bulgaria's Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria were ousted, new governments were chosen in free elections with mandates for economic reform. They promised a break with the old, inefficient economics and a taste of the free-market policies that Western Europe prosperous. People in both countries say things have not improved. Bulgarians lived relatively well on the food and energy bought by Zhivkov's liberal borrowing policies, so this has been the worst winter ever for many. Months of political bickering between a weak government and divided opposition prevented action on measures to improve living standards. Shelves in food store usually are empty. Bulgaria stopped making payments months ago on a foreign debt of more than $10 billion and is strapped for cash to import energy. ``If I could choose, I'd choose to live in a country where there is maybe less democracy but more goods,'' said Marina Popova, 27, who spends much of her time in a stuffy kitchen-living room with her husband, 3-year-old child and in-laws. ``We don't have enough wood to heat the whole house, and that's why during the day we all live in one room,'' she told a visitor to Kalugerovo, her village 80 miles southeast of Sofia. Little was for sale in the village store: cheese, packets of rice and cans of fish. A supply van that used to come fully loaded three times a week now delivers sporadically, said the store manager, who would not give her name. ``It may have been bad while Zhivkov was in power, but at least our shop was full,'' she said. Another resident, Sotyanka Sirakova, said life gets ``worse and worse'' in Bulgaria. Meat has been unavailable for four months and cooking oil for three, she said in a shabby room she shares with her husband. Mrs. Sirakova, 52, is an unemployed cleaning woman. Romanians suffered severely during the last decade of Ceausecu's rule, when he exported most of the country's food and raw materials to pay off the foreign debt. A sense of betrayal by the subsequent government is particularly strong in the western city of Timisoara, 300 miles from Bucharest, where the the uprising against the dictator began. ``The sacrifice was for nothing,'' Anna Kis said of the unfulfilled promise of better times. Mrs. Kis, a 42-year old widow, and Ms. Hosszu, 52, were interviewed after a four-hour shopping tour in Giroc, the working class district where some of the first protests occurred. Many people spend hours each day foraging for necessities. More than 100 people waited outside a butcher shop for gristly, unidentifiable cuts of meat. The two women said food rationing, normal under Ceausescu, had been introduced again in Timisoara. They said monthly limits per person were 4.4 pounds of sugar, 2 pounds of oil; 15 eggs; about half a pound of butter; about 3 pounds of flour and one chicken. When asked what she had bought, Mrs. Kis pulled a chunk of lard and a garlic clove from a battered sack. ``I wanted some salami or ham,'' she said. ``I also couldn't find any butter, eggs, flour or rice. You've got a ration card, but no food.'' Where food is concerned, she said, there is no difference between Ceausescu and President Ion Iliescu, who was elected in May. Iliescu is under increasing pressure to resign, in part because of the dismal economic picture. Many basic items of clothing are unavailable and others are too expensive, said Mrs. Kis, who earns 2,800 lei ($80) a month. She said shoes that cost 350 lei a year ago now sell for 1,500 lei, if they can be found at the official price. ``Even on the black market, you can't get what you want much of the time, and things are three times as expensive as in state shops,'' she said. Homes are warm in Giroc, Mrs. Kis said said, but the peole worry aout a fuel shortage. In the nearby village of Carpinis, nothing but piles of coal dust remains in the fuel depot. ``Only those who know the right people stay warm and fed,'' said Magdalena Wambach, the village teacher. ``It's just like under Ceausescu.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Weighs Release of Military Aid Congress Has Set Aside
DOC.TEXT:
Citing increased arms shipments to leftist rebels in El Salvador, the Bush administration may release $42.5 million in Salvadoran military aid which Congress recently set aside, U.S. officials say. Any such move would almost certainly touch off heated opposition from Democratic lawmakers who have become increasingly impatient with the continued American role in El Salvador's bloody civil war, now more than a decade old. Of particular concern to administration officials is evidence that the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front (FMLN) has received ``a substantial number'' of Soviet-made SA-14 anti-aircraft missiles, one of which was used to shoot down a Salvadoran fighter-bomber last month. Another missile shot down an AC-47 fixed wing gunship two weeks later. The officials, who asked not to be identified, said the major supply source for the FMLN continues to be the Sandinista-dominated military establishment in Nicaragua. Even though the Sandinista government was voted out of office in Nicaragua in February, arrangements agreed to by President Violeta Chamorro left the Sandinistas in control of the military. The commander in chief of the Nicaraguan armed forces, Humberto Ortega, has denied any Sandinista role in equipping the FMLN. The Bush administration had asked for $85 million in aid for the Salvadoran military for the current fiscal year. But Congress approved only half, setting aside the remainder in a bid to promote a negotiated settlement in El Salvador. Congress also was displeased with the pace of El Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani's investigation of the murders of six Jesuit priests last year. The aid could be released if President Bush concludes that the FMLN is continuing to import substantial quantities of weapons or is launching attacks non-combatant civilians. Recent FMLN military campaigns have claimed hundreds of lives, including some non-combatants, the State Department says. Release of the aid also could be approved if the administration concludes that the conservative Cristiani government is being threatened by an FMLN military offensive. The officials said the status of the $42.5 million in set aside aid is ``under review'' - meaning the administration is weighing the possibility of restoring it. Congressional sources said administration officials, in publicly discussing the possibility of releasing the $42.5 million set aside, are attempting ``to scare the rebels off the battlefield.'' Recent attempts at negotiating a settlement have bogged down. The administration says an FMLN demand for the liquidation of the Salvadoran military and its price for a settlement is unreasonable. The U.S. officials said the Soviets have confirmed sending SA-14s to Nicaragua and Cuba and did not authorize the transfer of any of these weapons to the FMLN. When questioned about an SA-14 launcher found at the site where the A-37 fighter-bomber was shot down, Soviet authorities confirmed that the item was supplied to the Sandinista Army in 1986, U.S. officials said. It was the first time the rebels had managed to down a Salvadoran military aircraft in 11 years of war. The FMLN cause seemed doomed last winter after Chamorro's victory over Nicaragua's Sandinista president, Daniel Ortega. A U.S. official, reflecting on the continuing Sandinista supply role, said ``They (the FMLN) are probably pleased and surprised at their ability to continue to receive supplies.'' The official added that Cuba also has been supplying the FMLN and training rebel recruits. After the two warplanes were shot down, the State Department announced on Dec. 7 that it was speeding up shipments of millions of dollars worth of military equipment to the Salvadoran armed forces.
If the administration releases the aid, congressional sources predict an angry reaction from some Democratic lawmakers who will argue that the case for such action is weak. One such source, asking not to be identified, said releasing the aid makes no political sense for Bush. ``Why would the president want to start a fight when he's trying to line up support behind his Persian Gulf policy?'' the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Days on the Subway: No Crime, No Shower, No Kidding
DOC.TEXT: They saw homeless people, a preacher giving a lively sermon, an accordion player, a violinist, a man playing a comb wrapped in wax paper and lots of rats and mice. But Charlie Redell and Roy Fox witnessed no muggings or drug deals during a three-day expedition through the entire subway system - which they say proves the subway is not the terror-a-moment adventure that some people expect. Redell, 17, and Fox, 51, a family friend, set out Thursday morning to ride every inch of subway track - 722 miles worth. They finished late Saturday, about six hours ahead of schedule, still riding on the $1.15 tokens they'd put in the turnstyles Thursday. Redell undertook the venture as a project for his humanities class at Townsend Harris High School. ``Many of my classmates live in Queens and have overprotective parents and they never ride the subway,'' he said. ``My main gal with the project is to show that everything isn't as horrible as people say. Roy and I were never bothered once. I never saw a knife and I never saw a gun.'' Fox, a former radio talk show host who is now the caretaker of a city-owned 18th century house in the borough of Queens, says he ``wanted to see just how far a $1.15 token could go. Seven hundred and twenty-two miles, that's not a bad deal.'' Fox says others have ridden every route in the subway system on one continuous trip, but as far as he knows, no one has ridden every inch of track. To do this, he and Redell went through many stations more than once, but on different tracks - uptown, downtown, local and express. In addition to the homeless people, musicians and vermin, their journey included two delays caused by a track fire and a power failure; a freezing ride in the middle of the night on an elevated section of track; a large woman dancing vivaciously to country music blasting from her radio; a man with a huge hole in the seat of his pants wearing no underwear; a man who kept threatening to slug his date; and a very drunk fellow named Walter who divulged his life story. ``All part of the free entertainment provided by the T.A.,'' said Fox. The Transit Authority had provided them with a list of working bathrooms, scheduled track work and station concession stands. The cuisine turned out to be a lot better than the candy and donuts they had anticipated buying. One night, Redell's mother met them at a station with dinner from McDonald's, which she served on her best china. A photographer who met them periodically when they beeped his pager brought broiled chicken and fruit, along with a table cloth and silk flowers. And a television camera crew gave them hot dogs. They slept only a few hours during the three days, however. When they finished, they looked like the homeless people they had shared cars with - hands black with grime, 3-day-old socks bunched down around their ankles, blue jeans filthy. What's next for the adventurers? ``A hot shower,'' said Redell.

DOC.HEAD: Queen's Granddaughter Baptized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to add date of princess' birth. Pick up 4th pvs, `The infant...'
DOC.TEXT: Princess Eugenie Victoria Helena of York, the youngest grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II, was the noisy center of attention Sunday at her baptism. Her cries were heard not only by about 130 people inside the church of St. Mary Magdalen on the queen's estate, but also by an estimated 1,500 people listening to loudspeakers placed outside. The princess, the daughter of Prince Andrew and the former Sarah Ferguson, was believed to be the first member of the royal family to be baptized in a public service. She was born March 23. The infant princess wore the silk and Honerton lace christening robe first worn by Queen Victoria's eldest daughter and by all royal babies since. Princess Eugenie's first tentative cries became increasingly obvious as the service progressed and she gave a particularly lusty cry at the moment of baptism, causing a sympathetic ripple of laughter among the crowd waiting outside in the cold. Fifteen members of the Royal Family, now gathering at Sandringham for their traditional Christmas celebration, attended the service. Missing was Prince Charles, who was visiting British forces in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Three Little Piggs Arrive In Time For Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Once upon a time, not so very long ago, in a hospital not too very far away, came three little Piggs. Triplets Thomas, Angela and Brittany are an early but welcome Christmas present for Thomas and Lottie Pigg, who had tried unsuccessfully for six years to have children. ``It's a blessing,'' said Mrs. Pigg, who had taken a fertility drug often linked with multiple births. The triplets were born at York Hospital on Dec. 14, eight weeks premature. Their mother went home Sunday, but the triplets, the couple's first children, are expected to remain in the hospital until February to gain more weight. Thomas, the firstborn, tipped the scales at 3 pounds, 13 ounces. Angela weighed 2 pounds, 5 ounces. Brittany, delivered last, weighed in at 3 pounds, 12 ounces. The couple, from White Hall, Md., learned in June that they would be parents of triplets. ``We had tried for so long to have children, and everything failed,'' she said. ``When they told me we were going to have triplets, I was in shock.'' Mrs. Pigg said she and her husband have heard ``Three Little Pigs'' jokes ``every day'' and are bracing for more of the same as the triplets grow up. ``You've got to have a sense of humor about it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Obscenity Issue at Center of Rift Between Theater Producer and NEA
DOC.TEXT: A friendly, 24-year alliance between the National Endowment for the Arts and New York theater producer Joseph Papp collapsed in bitter enmity last month after an acrimonious exchange of letters over the issue of obscenity in the arts. At the end, Papp had spurned nearly $748,000 in federal grants and accused NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer of betraying the arts community in a futile attempt to ``appease the fanatical zeal of the religious right.'' Frohnmayer accused Papp of ``inexcusable and self-serving'' behavior in rejecting the NEA grants to protest a congressional ban on federal support for arts projects that might be deemed obscene. Papp, president of the New York Shakespeare Festival, fired his parting shot in a Nov. 15 letter asking how Frohnmayer intended to implement new legislation which dropped the obscenity ban but requires the NEA to consider ``general standards of decency'' in its grant-making decisions. ``Your past record provides little assurance of an arts atmosphere free of subtle and not-so-subtle intimidation,'' Papp wrote. Copies of the private, seven-month exchange of letters between Papp and Frohnmayer were released by NEA headquarters in response to a Freedom of Information Act request by The Associated Press. In separate interviews Thursday, Frohnmayer and Papp made clear that neither was in a hurry to heal their breach. ``If we can restore relations with Saddam Hussein, anything is possible,'' Papp said in a telephone interview from New York. ``I suspect they'll come back at some point,'' Frohnmayer said, ``but I don't propose to do anything about it myself.'' Papp's battle with the NEA under Frohnmayer's leadership coincides with serious financial problems at the New York Shakespeare Festival, which Papp founded in 1954 in a church basement on the Lower East Side. The non-profit theater organization, largest in the United States, now includes the five-stage Public Theater in Manhattan, free Shakespeare performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, an annual Latin festival and numerous other theatrical ventures. Papp received his first federal grant, totaling $100,000 in 1966, a year after the arts endowment was created by Congress. Earlier this month, Papp announced the festival will lay off 30 of its 123 employees at the end of the year to save about $750,000 a year - just about the amount of NEA money he had turned away. ``It's totally a matter of economics,'' Papp said. The producer's battle with Frohnmayer was fought over anti-obscenity legislation which Congress passed in October 1989 at the behest of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. The NEA chairman has final authority to decide whether grants are approved or rejected under the law. Papp also objected to Frohnmayer's requirement that grant recipients sign an anti-obscenity pledge, even though it wasn't required under the law. The NEA chairman rescinded the pledge after Congress repealed the obscenity ban last October and substituted the ``decency standard.'' Relations between the two men began to sour when Papp wrote Frohnmayer on April 9 expressing dismay about the obscenity ban and misgivings about the ``unthinkable if not downright subversive'' act of accepting a $50,000 endowment grant under those conditions. Papp rejected the $50,000. The mood of the correspondence changed drastically after Frohnmayer in late June overruled an NEA panel of outside judges and rejected grants to four controversial ``performance artists'' whose solo stage acts usually deal with gay and lesbian issues, racism and politics. In a four-page, single-spaced letter dated July 3, Papp charged that Frohnmayer had ``sadly become Jesse Helms' enforcer, a censor, a role ill-befitting the leader of the arts in America'' by denying the four grants. ``You must realize, dear John, that no matter how far you go, you will never be able to appease the fanatical zeal of the religious right,'' Papp wrote. Papp urged Frohnmayer to reverse himself and approve the four grants, even if it meant possibly being fired by President Bush. ``Do you want praise from Senator Helms and his cohorts, or to live by your conscience and to be revered by Americans who believe in the arts as a crucial part of our democracy?'' Papp asked. Frohnmayer didn't write back this time. Instead, he rejected the appeals of the four grant applications - Karen Finley, Holly Hughes, John Fleck and Tim Miller. They sued Frohnmayer in federal court, charging that he violated the Constitution by denying the funds for political rather than artistic reasons. On Nov. 1, after Congress imposed the ``decency standard'' on arts endowment grants, Papp sent Frohnmayer a curt, three-paragraph letter. He wrote that ``unreasonable restrictive measures make it impossible for the New York Shakespeare Festival to continue its relationship with the National Endowment for the Arts.'' Accordingly, Papp said he rejected as ``unacceptable'' NEA grants totaling $323,000 which had been approved the previous May and July. Because Papp never claimed the funds before the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the undisbursed grant money automatically reverted to the U.S. Treasury. Frohnmayer was outraged. ``You sat on those grants throughout the duration of the fiscal year and now tell us that you will not use them, thus denying $323,000 to some other deserving arts applicant,'' he wrote Papp on Nov. 5. ``Your actions are inexcusable and self-serving,'' he added. Frohnmayer served notice he would withdraw three other Papp grant applications from consideration unless he heard from the New York producer by Nov. 16. In a Nov. 15 letter - the last of the exchange - Papp confirmed he was withdrawing the three applications for new grants totaling $375,000. That brought to $748,000 the federal funds - awarded or applied for - that Papp rejected.

DOC.HEAD: Ban Would Kill Biscayne Bay Sponge Fishing But Save the Bay
DOC.TEXT: The sponge fishermen of Biscayne Bay are feeling a squeeze on their livelihoods. A state proposal in its final drafts would ban sponge fishing in Biscayne National Park, covering about two-thirds of the sponge-fertile Biscayne Bay. Federal and state officials worry that continued removal of sponges would seriously threaten the bay's fragile ecosystem. The fishermen insist their activity doesn't hurt the bay's environment - also threatened by shore development and heavy recreational use - and keeps them and their families alive. ``I don't know what I'm going to do,'' said 77-year-old Pedro ``Chico'' Cordova, a Cuban immigrant who fishes with his son in Biscayne Bay. ``I've been doing this all my life. There's nothing I can do, except for this.'' Sponge fishermen have worked Biscayne Bay, which stretches about 50 miles from Key Largo to North Miami, for nearly 1{ centuries. The fishing continued even after the southern end, south from Key Biscayne, was declared a national park in 1980. A blight in the Mediterranean in 1987 destroyed most of the Mediterranean sponge population and forced a drastic increase in prices worldwide. The natural sponges are considered superior to man-made sponges in some types of cleaning and cosmetic applications. With the price increase, the industry exploded at the prime Florida sponge fishing sites in Biscayne Bay, Tarpon Springs and the Florida Keys. By 1989, as many as 30 boats with three or four men each were pulling sponges from the bay. The Mediterranean stock has since revived and the number of sponge fishermen in the bay has dropped to about 40. That's still too many for park rangers. ``It's in excess of what the Bay can handle,'' said Richard Curry, resource management coordinator for Biscayne National Park. Park officials say sponges are an irreplaceable component of a delicate marine ecosystem. They act as water filters and their porous bodies provide habitats for smaller organisms such as juvenile fish and crabs. Further, commercial fishing is contrary to the mandate of the National Park Service, the officials say. ``We're here to preserve and protect the resources, not preserve and utilize the resources,'' said Curry, who's studied the bay's ecosystem for 13 years. Responding to the Park Service's concern, the State Fisheries Commission recently passed the proposal to ban sponge fishing in the park. It will hold a public hearing on Jan. 8 and fine tune the plan by its meeting at the end of January. The present version of the plan calls for a gradual phaseout of sponge fishing in the park over the next year. Fishermen will be able to spend only two out of every four weeks on the water until Dec. 1, 1991, when the commercial fishing of sponges will be prohibited entirely. Curry says the sponge ban may presage a wider ban on other commercial fisheries in the bay. The Fisheries Commission estimated that fishermen harvested more than 1,600 pounds of sponges last year. Some use environmentally harmful methods of fishing, Curry said. They spread cooking oil on the surface of the water for better visibility and, in violation of the law, spend more than the 14 days on the water in boats with poor sanitary facilities, Curry said. In addition, officials say, sponges are being removed much faster than they can grow back. ``The pure numbers of fishermen indicated to us that the harvesting was in excess of what the bay could handle,'' said James A. Sanders, park superintendent. The fishermen - all Cuban immigrants - are bitter about the proposed ban and perceive it as a personal attack on their way of life. ``The workers are going to sue the government because you just can't throw the fishermen out on the street,'' said Cordova, who grew up in the sponge fishing town of Caibarien, Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: No Room at the Inn for Homeless on Lower East Side
LaserPhoto NY8
With AM-Columbus Dispute, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Joseph and Mary walked through streets of Manhattan's grim Lower East Side, past the makeshift tents of homeless people and run-down tenements juxtaposed with gentrified apartment buildings. They knock on a door. ``We are looking for warmth and a bed for the night,'' Joseph tells the man who answers, his arm around his pregnant wife. ``No,'' came the angry reply. ``Go, I say. For thou are poor, and there is no bed or rest here for thee.'' The scene was from an outdoor Christmas pageant staged Saturday by the Rev. George Kuhn. About 100 parishioners turned out to walk with the couple, singing hymns and carrying candles. But the story of a poor couple seeking warmth is more than a Bible story: It's one Kuhn hears daily as pastor of St. Brigid's, across the street from Tompkins Square Park, one of the city's largest encampments of homeless people. ``Our church opens right onto a place where 250 people are sleeping every night,'' Kuhn said. ``So it's very hard to preach the gospel and ignore the central people in the gospel: the poor.'' He delivers his message in the streets, marching in demonstrations for affordable housing, clashing with police and getting arrested again and again. Among the homeless and the squatters, who have learned not to trust anyone too quickly, he has a reputation as a sincere man who shares their do-it-yourself spirit. ``Here, if something's wrong, you fix it,'' said Calli Tumulty, a young woman living with a group of squatters in a row of abandoned city-owned tenements. ``That's what Father Kuhn does. He tries to fix things.'' Kuhn, 51, dislikes to be called a radical street activist. His is a religious pursuit. ``As a pastor of a parish, you live in the real world,'' he said. ``And our real world consists of drugs, AIDS, violence and homelessness.'' His church was built by Irish immigrants in 1850. The parish now is mainly Hispanic, and poverty is still rampant. Colorful murals put a bright face on otherwise crumbling buildings built more than a century ago. Creeping gentrification has forced some families out of their homes while others struggle with escalating rents. The struggles of the parish are obvious in Tompkins Square Park, where on a recent frigid day dozens of homeless people huddled around trash barrel fires while neighborhood children played on swings and slides. Twice last winter, the city tried to move the homeless out to shelters. But the homeless returned to their flimsy tents and shanties. A city count Dec. 13 found 104 people living there. Kuhn believes the number is more than twice that. Kuhn already had four arrests under his clerical collar - for anti-war and anti-nuclear protests - when he arrived at St. Brigid's in 1986. He stayed out of jail until he got involved last year with a group of squatters who occupied an abandoned school. He was arrested three times for crossing a police barricade to take them food before they were finally evicted. Last October, Kuhn was arrested along with 20 others after squatters attempted to occupy some vacant neighborhood apartments. In each arrest, the charges were eventually dropped. Kuhn has the tacit support of Cardinal John O'Connor and has never been reprimanded following any of his arrests, said Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York. Kuhn blames the city for moving too slowly, for not taking drastic measures - like taking over vacant buildings or giving squatters legal standing - to deal with desperate times. By his count, the city owns 200 abandoned buildings in the neighborhood. ``If anyone doesn't see the public crisis that this city is facing, with anywhere between 70,000 and 100,000 people homeless, there's something wrong with them,'' he said. Kuhn intends to continue doing what he can for the homeless and believes most of his 600 parishioners support him. ``The only real protection they have is Father George,'' said Peter Cruz, a church elder.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Hunt for Money as Well as Killer in Gainesville Slayings
DOC.TEXT: The hunt for the killer of five college students - which has no end in sight - has also become a search for dollars. Investigators will visit Washington early next month to lobby for financial aid. They have run up a $3 million tab while checking out more than 5,500 leads. Some $1.14 million in federal grants covered only a part of the overtime costs of the six agencies involved in a task force investigating the killings. Officials from the task force plan to meet to meet with Sens. Connie Mack and Bob Graham, among others, in hopes of getting more money. The Gainesville Police Department is already in the hole for $309,120 and the other agencies' expenses also are outstripping the amount of the grants. ``A city this size cannot afford that hit,'' said Patrick Callahan, budget coordinator for the Gainesville Police Department. Gainesville police are already cutting back on some programs and delaying implementation of others to continue paying for the investigation. ``We'll do what it takes. We are not going to base this investigation on available income,'' he said. ``We'll find the money, it's that important.'' The department, he said, is determined to pay for the investigation for a full year after the murders. That may not be long enough. ``There is nothing I'm aware of at this point in time to allow me to project when we'll solve this case,'' State Attorney Len Register said recently. The focus has faded from former University of Florida freshman Edward Lewis Humphrey, for weeks considered a strong suspect. He is currently serving a sentence in a mental institution for beating his grandmother. Gainesville Police Chief Wayland Clifton said he remains confident the case will be solved but cautions citizens not to let down their guard. ``Our assumption is he could strike again,'' Clifton said. Most of the 65 investigators who remain on the case are taking a break for the holidays and will return in January. Some Florida Department of Law Enforcement agents have moved out of motels and into apartments, telling relatives they could be here a year. ``It could be even longer,'' Register said. More than 300 investigators came in Aug. 29, after the last of five victims were found. The killings came on the eve of the fall semester's beginning as students moved into apartments and dorms - the excitement of a new school year on everyone's minds. ``Fall is kind of a semester of dreams. It's the semester you think you are going to get straight A's; you're going to find the girlfriend or boyfriend of your dreams; you've got a football team all set for a new season,'' said Michael Browne, University of Florida student body president. ``That was all taken away from us.'' The murders are still topics of conversation and there is still fear on the campus. The student newspaper, the Independent Florida Alligator, congratulated students earlier this month for making it through ``the most hellish semester in school history.''

DOC.HEAD: Egypt's Role Likely To Be Enhanced However Crisis Ends
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Egypt's traditional role as big brother to the Arabs has never been tested more than during its confrontation with the other major Arab power, Iraq. Analysts say President Hosni Mubarak passed the test well. No matter how the Persian Gulf crisis ends, they say, Egypt's role has been enhanced with Saudi Arabia and the smaller Persian Gulf states. Its importance, stemming mainly from its military strength and the political weight it carries with the West, probably will be increased for a long time to come. A likely scenario would be the oil-rich sheikdoms, especially Saudi Arabia, financing a standing Egyptian army as the backbone of regional security in the gulf. ``This is not viewed as an Egyptian rent-a-cop, nor is it viewed as a Saudi bailout,'' said Jim Zogby of the Washington-based Arab-American Institute. He said political and economic cooperation would be an integral part of the relationship. Egypt already has close to 30,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, part of a U.S.-dominated multinational force half a million strong. Mubarak and President Bush's administration pieced together the Arab force, involving Syrian and Moroccan troops as well, after Iraq's army invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and its president, Saddam Hussein, annexed the emirate six days later. Zogby and others said the basis of Egypt's new military prominence is a general unease with the presence of a quarter-million U.S. soldiers on Arab soil to protect Arabs from Arabs. Richard Murphy, former assistant secretary of state for the Near East and South Asia, sees among the Arabs ``a sense of shame that Arabs fouled the nest, but they want to take care of it themselves.'' The notion of American forces remaining in the area after the crisis ends ``in itself is uncomfortable for everybody,'' said Murphy by telephone from New York, where he is an analyst for the Council on Foreign Relations. And even if they did stay, he said, ``a United Nations flag would be more comfortable. But the Saudis want an Arab force.'' That means to a great extent an Egyptian force. Egypt has a standing army of half a million men and more than 600,000 reserves. It is the only Arab force capable of standing up to Iraq's million-man military. In Cairo, the thinking in the Foreign Ministry is that U.S. soldiers will be necessary for some time after Iraq is driven out of Kuwait. The gulf Arabs and Egypt need breathing room for organizing a regional defense force, Egyptian diplomats say. They also are talking about how the Arab force must be formed from within and Egypt's special role in it. ``Any Arab security system must emanate from within the Arab nation,'' Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid told an economics and political seminar at Cairo University. ``It should not be imposed from outside. If it is, it will definitely fail.'' Abdel-Meguid's chief aide, Minister of State Butros Ghali, said the reshaping of Egypt's role extends beyond shoring up weaker nations with its military might. ``One of the first objectives of Egyptian diplomacy once the gulf crisis is over will be to create a new momentum in favor of economic integration of the Arab World,'' Ghali told an interviewer in New York. With that, he said, can come political cohesion that would let the Arabs compete with a united Europe.

DOC.TEXT: After missing his scheduled court date last week, actor Rodney Grant was finally arraigned on two charges of unemployment fraud. Grant, who appears in the Kevin Costner film ``Dances With Wolves,'' was arrested in Lincoln on Monday on a year-old warrant for failing to appear in court a previous time, in December 1989. Grant, 31, was charged on two counts of obtaining Nebraska unemployment compensation by making false statements. Deputy Lancaster County Attorney Jan Lipovsky said Grant was apparently unaware of his arraignment Wednesday. After learning that he had missed that second court date, Grant returned to face the charges Friday. The misdemeanor charges stem from two one-week periods in June and July 1988, when he allegedly was employed but received unemployment compensation. Grant portrays the bold warrior Wind In His Hair in ``Dances With Wolves.'' Judge Richard Williams set a $1,500 personal recognizance bond for Grant. His next court appearance has not be scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: 22nd Game Postponed A Second Time
DOC.TEXT: The 22nd and possibly decisive game of the world chess championship between defender Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was postponed a second time, the organizers announced Sunday. A technical time-out was called so the game would not be played on Monday, Christmas Eve. Karpov took his third and final time-out on Saturday, pushing the 22nd game to Monday. Kasparov has used all his time-outs. With Christmas approaching, the president of the International Federation of Chess, Florencio Campomanas, reached an agreement with both players to put off the 22nd game until Wednesday. Regulations permit a technical time-out. Kasparov leads the series 11.5 to 9.5 and needs only a draw to gain the 12 points needed to win and retain the title. He will play white in the 22nd game, with Karpov defending with the black pieces. Kasparov has won the last three times he has played white in the nine games in Lyon. Karpov needs to win the final three games to take the title. He has won twice in the 21 previous games of this series. The two have played to a draw five times in the French portion of the championship. They drew 10 times in the 12 games played in New York between Oct. 8 and Nov. 7. Even if Kasparov clinches the title by reaching 12 points in the series, the two Soviet grandmasters will continue playing to see who wins the majority of the $3 million purse. If the overall series ends in a 12-12 draw, the prize money will be split. Kasparov won the title from Karpov in 1985 and defended it in 1986 and 1987. Karpov took the championship in 1975 when American Bobby Fischer refused to defend the title he won in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Santa May Not Make It But Hot Turkey Dinner Will
DOC.TEXT: It won't be Christmas dinner at home with roasted chestnuts and a roaring fire, but Desert Shield troops will have literally tons of turkey, roast beef and ham to feast on. ``Santa Claus is not going to be around probably to bring presents, so we're going to have to do something to make it a special day,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Wesley Wolf, food adviser for the U.S. military in Saudi Arabia. ``It's such a big day. This is really an important meal for us. We're trying to get a hot meal to everyone,'' Wolf said. Hot food is a big morale boost to the service members on duty in foxholes and guardposts, enduring the flies, heat, scorpions and desert isolation. As a touchof home cooking, the military has prepared 340,000 meals for Christmas. There are 280,000 U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, but Wolf over-ordered to make sure he had more than enough for every service member. Ingredients for the Christmas dinner were ordered in September and arrived a month ago. Reinforcements arriving in the country on Tuesday won't have to worry about missing Christmas dinner either. ``If a soldier walks in that day, we'll have a Christmas meal for him,'' said Wolf, who served as a cook in Vietnam. Ham will be served, even though pork products are banned in this Islamic kingdom. ``We keep it low profile. We don't make a big deal of it. We bring it in and handle it ourselves,'' Wolf said. The list for Christnmas Day cooking includes: 35,000 pounds of shrimp plus cocktail sauce; 108,000 pounds of canned ham; 172,000 pounds of roast beef; 150,000 pounds of rolled turkey; 4,000 whole turkeys; cranberry sauce; stuffing; 280,000 pounds of glazed sweet potatoes; mashed potatoes; mixed vegetables; a salad of tomatoes, lettuce and cucumbers; assorted breads; 35,000 pounds of fruitcake; 150,000 pies including apple, peach, pecan, pumpkin and minced meat; hard candies; mixed nuts; apples, oranges, grapes, tangerines and pears; coffee, tea, milk, soft drinks and egg nog; and 500,000 Mars and Snickers candy bars donated by Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa, New Polish President, Receives Former Communist Leader
DOC.TEXT: President Lech Walesa on his first full day in office Sunday received his predecessor, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's former Communist leader who had been excluded from the inauguration ceremony. During their 50-minute meeting at Belweder Palace, Jaruzelski ``shared his experiences of performing the presidential office'' with Walesa, according to a brief communique carried by the PAP news agency. Jaruzelski wished the new president well in his ``most responsible mission,'' PAP said, and Walesa in turn wished his old foe health and success. Jaruzelski, 67, the former Communist Party chief, interned Walesa and thousands of other activists during the martial law crackdown that began on Dec. 13, 1981. He was not invited to Walesa's inaugural ceremonies, and his parliament gallery chair was empty when Walesa was sworn in before the National Assembly on Saturday. Walesa, the 47-year-old shipyard electrician and Solidarity labor leader for a decade, was elected Dec. 9 in the nation's first popular presidential vote. Although condemned internationally and disliked at home for repressing Solidarity during the 1980s, Jaruzelski, a four-star army general, remained in power as president after Solidarity took control of the government. As president, Walesa will be chief of state and the military, and he may gain enhanced powers in a new constitution expected to be adopted in 1991. By means of the 1989 negotiations with the democratic opposition, Jaruzelski allowed a peaceful transition to a Solidarity-led government. He was elected president by the National Assembly in July 1989 but resigned early under pressure to complete the democratic reforms with national presidential elections. During his 17 months as president, he did not interfere with the government's radical economic and political reforms. Although secretive during most of his three-decade political career, Jaruzelski became more open to the press as president, granting interviews and allowing television cameras to show his home life. Jaruzelski has said he will devote himself to writing his memoirs.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon and Elvis, Four Presidents Are Top Postcards at Nixon Library
With AM-Reagan's Papers
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon opened U.S. dialogue with China nearly 20 years ago and the effects are still being felt - even at the gift shop of the Nixon Library & Birthplace. The shop recently received a letter from a man in China requesting its most popular postcard, that of Presidents Nixon, Ford, Bush and Reagan together at the library inauguration. ``The man who sent it talked about Nixon and relations between China and the U.S.,'' said library spokesman Kevin Cartwright. ``It was quite a letter.'' ``He requested that we not send the postcard in any kind of identifying envelope,'' said Cartwright, alluding to the recent communist crackdown on the movement for democracy in China. The best-selling postcard records the unprecedented public gathering of four presidents. The second-best seller strikes a lighter note: It is a picture of the 37th president shaking hands with Elvis Presley in the Oval Office. Earlier this year, Nixon library managers decided to pull the famous tapes of the Watergate scandal in favor of other exhibits. However, that hasn't stopped visitors or the flood of gift shop sales. Over 200 autographed copies of Nixon's autobiograhy, ``In The Arena,'' were purchased one day last week. Library managers estimate Nixon signed several thousand copies of the memoir of his political career. Although the book has a $21.95 list price, copies are selling for $10 at the library to encourage readership. The Odyssey, a store in Newport Beach which specializes in autographed items, bought about 100, expecting the value to rise. The Nixon library gift shop sells other books penned by the former president as well as Chinese-made panda bears, porcelain plates signed by presidents, clothing and quiz cards on the presidents.

DOC.HEAD: Grocery Stores Closed After Early-Morning Bomb Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Police barred holiday grocery shoppers from supermarkets Sunday after a bomb exploded and six other bombs were deactivated before stores opened. The authorities blamed guerrillas. No one was hurt, and damage was still being added up, said police spokesman Cesar Augusto Somoza. The explosion at 8:15 a.m. (9:15 a.m. EDT) ripped through a supermarket 200 yards from the President Rafael Callejas' offices, the spokesman said.
