The presidential offices were closed for the holidays. A police bomb squad deactivated six powerful bombs at three other supermarkets, the police spokesman said. Two of the six were discovered at a grocery store in a mall 300 yards south of the U.S. Embassy. Police ordered supermarkets to stay closed until the afternoon while they searched for bombs. Somoza linked the bombs to an announcement by the Morazan Liberation Front, which said on the radio Sunday it was beginning an offensive against Callejas' government for its economic policies. The 11-year-old Morazan Liberation Front detonated two other bombs earlier this month, police said. The organization, a militant wing of the Honduran Communist Party, is blamed for numerous dynamite attacks since 1983. Police said they had arrested two front members, Juan Jose Vaca Nunez, 30, and Marco Tulio Funez Duarte, 31, on suspicion of bombing and bombing attempts. Both are union leaders at a subsidiary of the Cincinnati-based banana company Chiquita Brands International Inc. The guerrillas' announcement said they ``initiated an offensive of solidarity with the people and against those who, not caring about Hondurans' suffering and oppression, do dirty business in the name of the governing National Party's structural adjustment policy.'' On March 12, barely two months after Callejas' inauguration, his administration put into effect a series of austerity measures that have crippled consumers' buying power. The administration approved a 300 percent increase in electricity, water and phone rates. Prices have soared for basic products such as meat, beans, milk, bread, eggs, and fuel. The cost of gasoline rose 147 percent between June and September to $5.56 a gallon. Callejas introduced the measures in an effort to offset Honduras' $600 million deficit and make payments on the country's $3.5 billion foreign debt. However, they resulted in raging inflation, calculated at 32 percent for the year by the government and as high as 100 percent by private economists. The Morazan Liberation Front said Sunday it has formed ``detachments of Hondurans to struggle for better living conditions for Honduras' poor.'' Police claim that the group detonated two high-powered bombs on Dec. 12 and 18 that injured one person and damaged three buildings in San Pedro Sula, 125 miles northwest of Tegucigalpa. The group is named for former president Francisco Morazan, who led an armed movement to unite the five countries of Central America in the early 1800s. The front, born during 14 years of military rule, initiated an unsuccessful boycott of 1980 legislative elections. Members have been accused of wounding at least 15 U.S. soldiers in dynamite attacks between 1983 and 1989. They have also been charged with three armed attacks on U.S. military convoys traveling Honduran highways.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Blames Killing of Seven Arabs on Mental Illness
DOC.TEXT: A cashiered Israeli soldier admitted in court Sunday that he shot and killed seven Arab workers seven months ago but said his actions resulted from mental illness, not criminal intent. The killings May 20 in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Lezion set off three days of rioting in the occupied lands in which 13 Palestinians died from army gunfire, refueling the 3-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation. Ami Popper, 21, from Rishon Lezion, admitted the shootings through his court-appointed attorney, David Krimilovsky, on the opening day of his trial in Tel Aviv District Court, Israel radio reported. District Attorney Nurit Schmidt, who is prosecuting the case, said she intended to prove Popper acted in cold blood and would call witnesses to testify that he behaved calmly during the shootings, the radio said. Popper is charged with killing seven unarmed Palestinian workers and wounding 11 others in a so-called slave market, a spot where Arabs gather for hire as day laborers by Israeli employers. Popper, armed with an Uzi submachine gun, ordered 50 Palestinians to sit on the ground, then raked them with gunfire. Arab survivors later said they obeyed his orders because he had a gun and was wearing Israeli army pants. After Popper's arrest, authorities said he was deranged and despondent over a failed love affair. Army officials said Popper was dishonorably discharged from service for being absent without leave. Popper's attorney said his client was mentally incapable of understanding the charges against him, but a panel of five court-appointed psychiatrists found him competent to stand trial. Family members later complained they could not afford examination by independent psychiatrists. A former girlfriend, whose name was banned from publication by the court, testified Sunday that she broke off an affair with Popper two weeks before the Rishon Lezion killings and that he threatened to kill himself, the radio said. It also quoted the woman as saying Popper came to her on the day of the shootings and told her ``I did a terrible thing. I fired at 15 Arabs to be far away from you.'' The woman also said Popper told her that at age 13 he had been tied to a tree and raped by a man. After his arrest, Popper said he had been raped by seven Arabs, one of whom was a victim in the Rishon Lezion shootings. Family members said at the time that they'd never heard the story. Those killed in Rishon Lezion were from the occupied Gaza Strip, and rioting began there shortly after the shootings. It later spread to the West Bank and neighboring Jordan, which has a large Palestinian population.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Haaretz Editor Gershom Schocken Dies in Tel Aviv
DOC.TEXT: Gershom Gustav Schocken, editor of the respected Israeli daily Haaretz for more than 50 years and one of the country's most acclaimed journalists, has died. He was 78. Schocken died Saturday at Shiba Hospital in Tel Aviv of what Haaretz described as a ``malignant disease'' that had been diagnosed a year ago. An editor at the Hebrew daily declined to give further details. Schocken was born in September 1912 in Zwickau, Germany, and was the eldest son of Shlomo Salman Schocken, a businessman and art collector who established the Schocken Publishing Houses. He studied economics at Heidelberg University from 1932-1933 and, with the rise of the Nazis in 1933, moved to Palestine, where he worked for the Anglo-Palestine Bank. Schocken's father purchased Haaretz in 1937 and he became a business manager at the newspaper. Schocken was appointed editor in 1939 and held the post till his death. In 1955, Schocken was elected to Israel's Knesset, or parliament, as a member of the Progressive Party. Schocken was one of the founders of Itim, Israel's national news agency, and he was named International Editor of the Year by the New York-based World Press Review in 1983. ``There never was another journalist like Schocken in Israel,'' a longtime Haaretz reporter, Joel Marcus, wrote in Sunday's edition of the newspaper. ``A part of Schocken remains within many of us.'' ``For him, freedom of the press meant first of all the journalist's duty to be precise, to expose the establishment's failures and not to be servile in front of it, to write truly about a true thing and adhere to it,'' Marcus wrote. Schocken is survived by his wife, a daughter and two sons. His funeral was held Sunday in Tel Aviv.

DOC.HEAD: State Museum Decks the Halls for Christmas, 1850s Style
DOC.TEXT: Mahala Roach tried an innovation for Christmas 1851. ``The children had such a number of gifts that I made a Christmas tree for them; Mother, Aunt and Liz came down to see it; All said it was something new to them,'' she wrote in her diary that year. ``I never saw one but learned from some of the German stories I had been reading.'' She didn't describe the tree, but it probably looked something like the little orange tree in the living room of the ``1850 House'' - the Louisiana State Museum's re-creation of a period French Quarter apartment. ``People used what they had. Mostly either crepe myrtle or mock orange,'' said Dot Mouton, who led a museum tour. Gilded nuts and apples hang from the branches along with lacy handkerchiefs, a paper doll, a top, a ring, a necklace, a tiny stuffed bear, small red and gold paper cornucopias, and a few small wrapped boxes. The gilded nuts might have held small gifts. ``A lot of people don't realize that the nut was a surprise. You might have a nut or you might have a little gift,'' said Claire Conlin, a former history professor who researched Christmases past for the museum. ``Of course, that was a walnut because it was easier to glue back together.'' Most gifts weren't wrapped. ``Wrapping wasn't important until the end of the century,'' said Mrs. Conlin. She said the famous Swedish opera star Jenny Lind, during a Christmas stay in North Carolina, wrapped her gifts as a joke. Instead of wrapping the presents to keep them secret, they were kept hidden until the tree was decorated - and children weren't allowed into the parlor with the Christmas tree until the day they got their presents. In addition to toys around the base of the tree, there also is a pitcher and sponge. ``You notice the candles for lighting on the tree. There would be a servant at the tree all the time in case of fire,'' said Ms. Mouton. Mahala Eggleston Roach was from Vicksburg, Miss., rather than from New Orleans, but the customs were the same, said Mrs. Conlin. She said Mrs. Roach's diary was used because it had so many Christmas entries. ``I've researched a number of places in the South. ... I've also researched in Chicago during the same period. ... The customs were very much the same,'' she said. One entry in the diary shows that Christmas stockings weren't hung only for children. ``I found in my stockings a beautiful gold cross, a pair of Etruscan sleeve buttons and two bottles of wine on the table,'' Mrs. Roach wrote in 1860. And yes, she probably did hang up both of her stockings. ``They seem to have hung up more than one stocking. Even in sketches, if there are two children in bed, there seem to be four stockings hung up,'' said Mrs. Conlin.

DOC.HEAD: Students Demand Immediate Trial of Ershad
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 chanting students marched through the streets of Dhaka on Sunday, demanding the immediate trial of deposed President Hussain Muhammad Ershad and his associates, witnesses said. ``Ershad must be tried immediately!'' the demonstrators chanted. Ershad, a former army general who seized power in a bloodless coup eight years ago, stepped down Dec. 6 following nearly two months of often violent street protests. In the port city of Chittagong, meanwhile, groups of rival students fought each other with bombs, revolvers and sticks, injuring more than 50, police and witnesses said. They said students also looted and ransacked at least 30 shops in the city. Many of those demonstrating Sunday in Dhaka were students from Dhaka University and had been at the forefront of the drive to oust Ershad. The former president was put under house arrest Dec. 12, but has not yet been charged. The caretaker government of acting President Shahabuddin Ahmed also ordered the arrests of three top Ershad aides: Vice President Madud Ahmed, Deputy Prime Minister Shah Moazzem and Home Minister Mahmudul Hassan. On Friday, police arrested former Industries Secretatry Mosharaf Hossain and his wife, Zeenat. Police are looking for 11 more top former officials. A student leader, Khairul Kabir Khokhon, warned that there were still enough pro-Ershad officials in the government to hinder the country's ransition from dictatorship to democracy. He said the government must rid itself of all military and civil officials associated with Ershad's rule. The students said they would hold nationwide demonstrations Dec. 26 to press for the trial of Ershad and his associates. Witnesses said the clashes in Chittagong erupted when supporters of the All Party Students Action Committee attacked two colleges to avenge the beating Saturday of their supporters by members of the Islami Chattra Shibir, or Islamic Students Organization. More than 100 students and at least 30 teachers were injured in clashes between the two rival groups Saturday. Saturday's clashes began when members of the Islamic Students Organization -which had been agitating for the removal of the university's vice chancellor - beat up students attending classes. A senior police official in Chittagong said on condition of anonymity that members of the two rival groups were moving around the city with weapons and sticks.

DOC.HEAD: Six Beaten at Home for Elderly by Pipe-Wielding, Bible-Toting Attacker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Emanu-el cq in last graf
DOC.TEXT: A Bible-toting assailant broke into a home for elderly Jewish people Saturday night and attacked six residents with a pipe, but officials discounted bigotry as a motive for the assault. Police said he made no anti-Semitic comments during or after the attack, and a Jewish leader said the man simply appeared to be a ``deranged individual.'' One man and five women, ranging in age from 76 to 90, from the Golden Acres Home for Jewish Aged were taken to Baylor University Medical Center. Five of the injured were discharged Sunday, with one woman remaining for observation, said hospital administrator Wilbur B. Smith. Two of the six suffered concussions, said hospital spokeswoman Nancy Rhodes. The others had cuts and bruises. Names weren't released. ``They really are basically very stable and doing OK,'' she said. Police said the attacker, in his early 20s, broke into the 255-resident nursing home shortly before 9 p.m. by smashing the glass of the front door. Carrying a Bible and a four-foot section of pipe, he went to a second-floor recreation room, where the six residents were sitting, and beat them. ``He told them not to be fearful,'' said Herbert Shore, the home's retired administrator who rushed there after hearing of the attack. Police were unsure of the man's identity Sunday, saying he had given thm several names. He was taken to Parkland Memorial Hospital, authorities said. ``He was acting alone and may have been deranged as far as we can tell,'' Shore said. Police said the man would be charged with six counts of aggravated assault or injury to an elderly person. Both are felonies. ``Clearly, it's a horrible act by what seems, at this hour, to be a deranged individual,'' said Mark Briskman, regional director of the B'nai B'rith Anti-Defamation League. ``I think it's more random than targeted,'' Briskman said after talking to police. ``You're talking about a guy who is high on something. You're talking about an individual, not a group of individuals.'' But, he added, ``It is absolutely shocking and despicable if (the elderly) were targeted because it was a Jewish facility.'' Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman of Temple Emanu-el said the nursing home tightened security a couple of years ago after threats from skinheads who espouse white supremacist and anti-Semitic views.

DOC.HEAD: Trials of Rioters Were Fair, Legal Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Legal officials on Sunday responded to international criticism over harsh sentences meted out to anti-government rioters, saying the trials were open and all defendents had access to defense lawyers. The officials, in interviews with the state ATA news agency, also said investigations against some suspects had been suspended for lack of evidence, while others whose cases went to trial were found innocent. On Saturday, 12,000 Albanians gathered for the first legal opposition rally, shouting demands for the release of political prisoners and more reform in their until recently Stallinist land. Chants of ``Freedom!'' alternated with cries of ``Democracy!'' and ``We want Albania to be like Europe!'' at the one-hour rally held in Tirana's Students' City. Speakers also demanded press freedom. Student protests about slum-like dormitories there swelled two weeks ago into demands for democracy and helped force the ruling Communists to allow opposition parties. Riots erupted in mid-December. Thousands of angry protesters burned and ransacked stores and other buildings in several cities including Durres on the coast and Shkodra in the north. Nearly 200 of the hundreds arrested went on trial Dec. 19. One of the more than a dozen sentenced a day later received a 20-year prison term, while others received 15 years, leading to criticism from human rights organizations abroad. ATA quoted Franc Jakova, and Rustem Syziu, chairmen of the barristers' college in Shkodra and in Durres as saying all had defense lawywers at request and free of charge. ``The trials have been conducted ... with open doors and the advocates have performed their duty in defense of the accused ...,'' ATA quoted the two as saying. In Durres, 11 cases had been suspended by Sunday and ``some of the accused are declared innocent,'' they said, according to ATA, which suggested the trials were continuing. The official trade union declared its independence from the ruling Albanian Labor Party Saturday, in another move documenting the Communist authorities new tolerance. Genc Resuli, head of the union's International Department, said the labor group pledged to work for higher pay and better working conditions, including a cut in the work week from six to five days. Life in Albania' obsolete factories is said to be abysmal. Many Albanians complain that rising food prices mean they struggle to get by on wages averaging $50 a month. Resuli said he expected the right to strike to be included in a new constitution being worked out by a group headed by President and Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia. The union was supportive, however, of the leadership's crackdown on the rioters despite its independence declaration, ATA reported Sunday. Union head Sotir Kocollari cited a report by his organization that ``expressed the indignation for the actions of diversion, plunder and destruction committed by some people,'' during the riots, said ATA. The union approved the rioters' sentences, the news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Since Gulf Crisis, Confrontations with Religious Police Rising
DOC.TEXT: A prominent family has demanded floggings for four religious policemen who they say forced their daughter's car off the road and roughed up the 20-year-old student because they believed she was dressed immodestly. The incident is one of several indicating the rising tension between Westernized Saudis and Islamic conservatives. ``The conservatives are reasserting their control,'' one Saudi diplomat said on condition of anonymity. Issues that link religion and politics are highly sensitive in the kingdom and no sources wanted to be quoted by name. The rigid Moslems say they are enforcing Islamic laws as founding prophet Mohammed would have wanted. They are especially vigilant in enforcing the ban on alcohol and socializing between the sexes as well as enforcing modest dress for women, which they interpret as head-to-toe covering. Formally known as committees for Encouraging Virture and Preventing Vice, the police are usually called muttawiin, or volunteers. They reject wearing bands around their headscarves, as many Saudis do, as unnecessary adornment. They wear short thobes, as the Saudi men's robe is called, and some carrylong thin camel prods. The sources said the government, concentrating its forces on the confrontation with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, does not want tension over social issues. ``In this kind of environment the last thing the ruling family wanted to do was start experimenting with society's traditions,'' a Western diplomat said. The government has tried to calm the religious elements that have criticized the influx of hundreds of thousands of foreign troops to defend the kingdom since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. And in an attempt to diffuse the situation, the government recently appointed Dr. Abdul Aziz ibn Abdulrahman Al-Saeed president of the religious police. Al-Saeed was educated at the Al-Azhar University - the oldest Islamic university - known for encouraging debate on Islamic Issues. Al-Saeed told the Okaz newspaper that the worst excesses of the religious police would be curbed, but he said the force would be more active. ``They should deal with people nicely and argue with them for the better, as the Koran prescribes,'' he said, referring to the holy book of Islam. In the latest incident Thursday, the daughter of a prominent Riyadh family had just left a tennis game in the diplomatic quarter. She was riding in the car with two foreign maids and a Sudanese driver, family members said. Religious police in another car signaled them to pull over, but the girl told the driver to dash for home. The muttawiin bashed into the car repeatedly in a freeway chase over several miles, forcing the car to stop. When the four would not open their doors, the police - aged 16 to 22 - smashed the windows and hauled out the driver. They pulled the maids' hair and then tussled with the girl when she tried to prevent them from driving the car. They called her names and accused her of immodest dress and wearing make-up. The family said her hair was covered and she was not wearing cosmetics. The traffic police interceded and summoned the girl's brothers. Under Islamic law, when a girl is unjustly insulted in public her family has the right to ask for retribution and they asked for 80 lashes. Riyadh Governor Prince Salman ordered the four men jailed while the investigation is under way, the family said. A November protest in which 40 women defied the traditional ban on women driving by taking to the highways of Riyadh proved a rallying cry among conservatives. Religious police have since stationed themselves outside the diplomatic quarter, near upscale shopping centers and women's universities. The number of confrontations has jumped markedly and a few have involved members of the royal family - unheard of previously. Foreign women have had their cars stopped and been jailed overnight, allegedly for not covering their heads, diplomats said. The religious police raided a diplomatic party in Riyadh in November and their rough treatment of guests prompted an official protest. In late November, police climbed over walls into the villa of a rich perfume manufacturer in Jiddah where a party involving liquor and single women was under way. An Islamic judge handed down sentences of up to two years.

DOC.HEAD: Police Scatter Anti-Government Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Riot police Sunday charged about 200 anti-government demonstrators in the capital, but most of the protesters regrouped later. Other small protests were reported in several other Romanian cities. There were no reports of serious injuries anywhere. A day earlier, about 1,000 anti-government demonstrators rallied in Bucharest as government officials commemorated the first anniversary of the fall of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. On Sunday, demonstrators in Bucharest's University Square fled after several dozen police in riot gear rushed them. The police charged after a car sped through the crowd and grazed one of the demonstrators. It was not clear who was in the car. Anti-government protests have been growing since President Ion Iliescu and the National Salvation Front government of Premier Petre Roman overwhelmingly won democratic elections in May. Reforms aimed at moving toward a market economy have driven up prices, and basic goods are often unavailable, causing widespread dissatisfaction. Also, many Romanians believe Iliescu, who was once a minister under Ceausescu, and other government officials have not broken with the authoritarian policies of the past government. More than 100,000 students and hundreds of professors across the nation are symbolically continuing a boycott of classes through winter vacation. Their anti-government protest began in mid-December, before winter break began. Navigators of the state airline Tarom have been on strike for higher wages for more than a week, paralyzing all internal flights and stranding hundreds of international travelers. Ceausescu fled on Dec. 22, 1989, as hundreds of thousands of people were gathering to demand the end of his 24-year rule. He and his wife were captured and executed Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Shopping at Full Tilt in Unified Germany
With AM-Toyless Christmas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Never mind the slow Christmas sales in the United States and Britain. German merchants are enjoying a holiday boom, fueled by 16.6 million eastern Germans hungry for consumer products after decades of deprivation. Shoppers have been standing a dozen deep at German cash registers this Christmas season, elbowing and pushing their way to snatch up everything from expensive video recorders to chocolate Santas. In a weekend report, the German retailers' association estimated Christmas sales in the united Germany at $18 billion. Nearly 70 percent of the stores surveyed reported sales were up this Christmas season compared with last year, although no percentage of increase was given. There is ``an overwhelmingly positive mood in the retail stores,'' the Association of German Retailers said. Overall retail sales in Germany for the entire year are expected to reach $465 billion, up a hefty 12 percent from 1989. The annual figure will be a post-war record. The figures tell only part of the story. Beyond that are packed stores, harried sales clerks and streets filled with shoppers. In downtown Berlin, shoppers from eastern Germany and Eastern Europe are snapping up everything in sight. ``We don't have it,'' say sales clerks fielding dozens of demands. ``Oh, that's been sold out for a long time.'' Watches, computer and electronics products and toys are the leading sellers. Jewelry and other big-ticket items are often in hot demand as well. Berlin's grocery stores are having a hard time keeping supplies in stock of Christmas baking staples such as almonds and raisins. Berlin's Tagesspiegel newspaper said Sunday the city was enjoying ``the sales of a century.'' The Tagesspiegel reported that Berlin would see a 30 percent jump in sales compared with last year. That would be a record-breaking increase. Richard Hennig, the manager of one huge Hertie department store, told the newspaper that ``hardly any department'' has been left out of the Christmas sales rush. Just how long the good times in Germany can go on remains to be seen. Recessions are looming in the United States and Britain, two of Germany's big export markets. Many financial experts are predicting an overall economic slowdown next year, as the full costs of German unification hit the country's manufacturers and consumers. The countries reunited on Oct. 3. But for now, the buying frenzy is unabated. In Berlin's far western section of Staaken, close to former East Germany, a mother went to a Woolworth store back in November to search for a Barbie doll accessory for her daughter's Christmas stocking. ``We don't have that because all the people from eastern Germany are coming over and buying everything up,'' the store clerk said as he dashed from one customer to another. Store detectives are being kept busy, too, by an increase in shoplifting. A sign in the window of one store in Berlin's Spandau district said the rise in theft had been ``catastrophic.'' The demand is also swamping the huge German mail-order houses, which pride themselves on promptly filling customers' orders. Some customers of the Otto catalogue store have been getting letters saying that the high number of orders ``from East and West'' have slowed delivery. The house said that as a result, it could not keep its usual promise of deliveries in time for Christmas.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles' Visit is Christmastime Boost for British Troops
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles climbed into the high-tech cockpit of a British Tornado jet Sunday and said he'd love to go for a ride someday, but that he was probably getting too old. The 42-year-old heir to the British throne, who flew with a Phantom jet squadron in the early 1970s, ran into two members of his old Royal Air Force unit during a pre-Christmas visit to British units at an airbase in eastern Saudi Arabia. ``It's a Christmas boost for all the troops. We tend to feel a little bit forgotten out here,'' said Flight Lt. Alan Whyte, 30, who was with 29 Squadron, the prince's old unit, before switching from Phantoms to Tornados. Wing Commander Andy Moir, 44, who is two years older than the prince and still flying Tornados, had a short message for him: ``We're prepared and confident.'' He sat on the edge of the two-seat interceptor as Charles checked out the aircraft, which has been training to do lower-level intercepts in tandem with U.S. F-15s. The Tornado was armed with four Sidewinder heat-seeking missiles and four Skyflash radar-guided missiles. A red sign at the entrance to the hangar said: ``Danger Aircraft Armed.'' Asked whether he'd like to go for a ride in a Tornado, Charles smiled and said: ``One day, yes. I think I'm getting too old for this.'' Charles said the British airmen and pilots from the 43rd Fighter Squadron were ``very pleased'' with the cooperation they've gotten from the Americans. ``I wanted to find out how these characters are getting on,'' the prince said after climbing down a flight of movable stairs from the cockpit. ``They're doing a marvelous job, as always.''

DOC.HEAD: Car Thieves Nabbed Trying to Steal Undercover Police Van
DOC.TEXT: Of all the cars and trucks in the shopping mall's parking lot on one of the year's busiest shopping days, a quartet of would-be car thieves picked on a police surveillance van. ``It was hard to keep from laughing,'' Mike Link, one of three officers hiding in the back of the van Saturday when one of the group climbed inside and turned the key. The would-be thief was grabbed from behind by a Lakeland police officer and arrested with his buddies. ``He was definitely surprised, because he screamed a lot,'' said Link. The van was part of a special unit, including foot patrols and undercover cars, dispatched to the Lakeland Square mall to combat holiday-related parking lot crime. Undercover officers first spotted the four suspects walking through the lot and flipping up door handles. They approached the van and were about to break in but too many shoppers were nearby, Link said. The thieves moved on to a neighboring strip mall. The police followed in the 1985 Chevrolet van. This time, one of the teen-agers got in, turned the key, and was nabbed. The charges against the four included grand theft and resisting arrest.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 191 To Be Tried This Week in Moroccan Violence
DOC.TEXT: At least 191 people arrested for taking part in violent protests this month are to be tried Monday and Tuesday in Rabat, Fez, Tangier and Kenitra. They face charges of rioting, disobedience and disturbing public order. On Friday, 39 people were sentenced in Tangier to jail terms ranging from two to four months for their part in the riots that killed at least five people, according to the government's account. Eleven of the sentences were suspended. Labor unions and human rights officials say more than 30 people died. Violence flared Dec. 14 when a general strike called by disaffected workers and unions degenerated into widespread looting and arson, most of it apparently committed by people not involved in the strike. The government later pledged to raise workers' salaries, improve social benefits and conduct an investigation into the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Cruzan's Father: She Would Want To Die
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan's parents say they'll face a difficult adjustment after their daughter's death but welcome an end to her nearly eight years in a vegetative state. The 33-year-old woman remained in deteriorating condition Sunday, 10 days after a judge allowed her parents to order her feeding tube removed. Doctors say her condition, brought on by a 1983 traffic accident, is irreversible. ``The future right now is a great big question mark,'' her father, Joe Cruzan said in an interview published Sunday by The Joplin Globe. ``It will be extremely difficult to cope with the transition after eight years of constant stress when the first thing you do is to come home and check the mail and the message machine,'' he said. ``It's like coming into a different land.'' The father urged anti-euthanasia activists camping in freezing temperatures outside the southwestern Missouri hospital to pray for his daughter. ``I think we should concentrate our prayer on God's will for Nancy. If he wants her to be healed, he will heal her,'' he said. ``If not, that he will make her death quick and painless.'' His wife, Joyce Cruzan, said it's time to let go. ``At least we'll know Nancy's at peace,'' the mother said. ``Somewhere out there Nancy's still tied to this body by a thread. We are going to snip that thread and then she will be completely free.'' Mrs. Cruzan said her daughter's condition has not changed much since the nutrition and hydration was stopped Dec. 14: ``We haven't seen a lot of change; her face may be a little thinner.'' Doctors have said she likely will die this week. With a feeding tube, they said, she could have stayed alive another 30 or 40 years. A candlelight vigil was held Saturday night at the Lawrence County jail for protesters arrested Tuesday when they tried to reach Ms. Cruzan's room. They were released late Saturday, sheriff's officials said. Joe Cruzan told the newspaper that if his daughter could make the decision, she would reject attempts to keep her alive. ``There are people on this floor right here, terminal cancer patients, whoif they don't want their food, are not force-fed,'' he said. ``I have never had anyone tell me they would like to live like this.'' Various courts last week denied attempts by by anti-euthanasia activists to force the state to resume feeding Ms. Cruzan. The Rev. Patrick J. Mahoney, a Protestant minister who runs the Center for Christian Activism in Boca Raton, Fla., asked the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis on Saturday to reconnect Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube. The appeals court has not set a date to hear Mahoney's petition.

DOC.HEAD: With New Hopes For Peace, Christmas is Again Celebrated In Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Omar, a Moslem taxi driver, dons his red Santa Claus suit and fluffy white beard every morning to deliver a toy store's Christmas gifts in Moslem west Beirut. Lebanon, with 17 known religious sects, once observed all religious holidays. But that tolerance died amid the bloodletting of nearly 16 years of civil war. Christmas celebrations were further muted in 1985, when pro-Iranian Shiite fundamentalist gunmen cracked down on ``un-Islamic activities.'' Now, with new efforts to end the civil war, the city's Christian areas are again celebrating the holiday, and the Moslem sector is joining in. Christmas carols echo through the Hamra commercial district of Moslem west Beirut, Christmas trees and other festive decorations are up in the streets just as they are in the eastern Christian sector. Omar - that's the only name he would give - has been hired by toy shop owner Fawziya Makkouk, a Moslem woman. He said he found nothing strange in delivering toys to Moslem as well as Christian children to celebrate a Christian ritual. ``I like children,'' said Omar, who has three of his own. ``I like making them happy. By delivering the toys I also make some money. I also get some toys free for my kids.'' Even now, it's not all sweetness and light. Political rivalries remain, and the future is uncertain in a city wrecked by war. Municipal electricity is rationed to three hours a day because of battle damage. Garbage is piled up at street corners. Whole blocks of the city are in ruins. And there's real economic hardship after years of fighting, so most people don't have much to spare for Christmas. But for now at least, the fundamentalists of Hezbollah, or Party of God, and other Christian and Moslem militias have gone. Gone too is the Green Line, the forbidding, fortified demarcation line between Moslem west Beirut and the eastern Christian sector. It had run like a jagged scar through the city since civil war erupted in April 1975. The militias have pulled out of the capital under an effort by President Elias Hrawi to end the conflict in which an estimated 150,000 people were killed. The Lebanese Army has moved back in to restore long-absent law and order. There is widespread optimism that Hrawi, backed by the Syrians, will be able to succeed in bringing peace despite the repeated failures of similar efforts in the past. Most Beirutis are praying that the violence is behind them and that Christmas will help bring the Lebanese together again. For Ghassan Abdallah, a liberal Shiite Moslem businessmen, this year's celebration is special. He has reserved a table at a restauarant overlooking the Mediterranean in the Moslem sector for a party ``with my Christian friends.'' ``They stopped coming to west Beirut when Hezbollah got rough in 1985,'' he said in an interview. ``But this year we're going to have a reunion. ``I hope the militias will be disbanded altogether so that we can get rid of them once and for all,'' Abdallah said. ``We're not scared of the militias any more,'' said Bassam Itani, the Sunni Moslem owner of a toy shop in west Beirut's Zarif district. ``Greater Beirut's now under army control and we're really relaxed. The fundamentalists can't threaten us any more.'' Mrs. Makkouk, whose store in the Moslem Zaydaniyeh district, said last year, she hadn't dared to have a Santa in her shop. She said business was good now, but pointed to the constant dwindlind of the Lebanese pound, once the Middle East's most stable currency. The pound was pegged at $2.50 when the war broke out in 1975. On Friday, it was 890 pounds to the dollar on Beirut's money market. Store owners said that a small plastic Christmas tree costs the equivalent of $25, a set of decorations another $15 and a ``humble gift'' at least $10. ``That adds up to the minimum monthly salary decreed by the government,'' Mrs. Makkouk said. ``Not many people can afford that.'' The currency slide has sent prices sky high in Lebanon, which imports more than 85 percent of its goods. ``This morning a little boy came to me with 800 pounds, which was the equivalent of $1 yesterday,'' Mrs. Makkouk said. ``He wanted to buy a toy car. The price last week was 800 pounds because the dollar was worth that. But now it's changed. I couldn't sell the toy.''

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon's Premier-Designate Facing Difficulties
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister-designate Omar Karami is having difficulty forming a national reconciliation government charged with ending 15 years of civil war. The Phalange Party, the biggest right-wing Christian political force in Lebanon, has joined the nation's main Christian militia in refusing to participate in Karami's projected cabinet. The move dampened Karami's chances of quickly forming a broad-based new government to replace that of Prime Minister Salim Hoss, who resigned with his 14-man cabinet on Thursday. Both the Phalangists as well as Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia claim Karami plans to bring in more pro-Syrian Christians than right-wingers. ``Those potential members of the cabinet do not represent the Christian community. Their wide presence in the cabinet creates an imbalance in favor of the Moslems,'' said a Phalangist statement published Sunday. ``Such a government will murder reconciliation rather than bring it about,'' the statement said. It was alluding to Elie Hobeika, Geagea's main Syrian-backed Maronite Catholic rival, and Assad Hardan, a senior official of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party. The party is a secular Lebanese leftist faction that advocates the merger of Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, Jordan, pre-Israel Palestine, Kuwait and Cyprus in a greater Syria. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, has 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the Arab League. Geagea's Lebanese Forces has charged that a cabinet made up of 30 politicians and warlords as President Elias Hrawi and Karami envisage would be ``a Tower of Babel.'' The militia also contended that Karami lacked the statesmanship and national prestige that the U.S.-educated Hoss enjoyed as a veteran of Lebanese politics for the past 14 years. Karami, 55, a Sunni Moslem, surfaced on the political stage only three years ago, when he inherited the leadership of the northern provincial capital of Tripoli from his elder brother, the late Prime Minister Rashid Karami. The elder Karami, the longest serving prime minister in Lebanon's 47 years of independence, was assassinated by a bomb explosion aboard an army helicopter in north Lebanon June 1, 1987. One of Lebanon's three strongest militias, the Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, has also refused to join Karami's government. ``The new government is certain to lack the vision and the minimum degree of harmony required to resolve the nation's woes,'' a Hezbollah statement said. Another major militia, Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party, has earlier expressed reservations about the government change. That party predicted Karami's cabinet would be an ``untidy government that would stumble upon its first steps. This could create a dangerous power vacuum.'' The new government, when formed, faces the task of disbanding the various warring militias and enforcing an Arab League-brokered peace plan that parliament ratified Aug. 22. It also is expected to map out a plan for reconstructing war-ravaged Beirut and shoring up the economy. The new government must also fill 31 vacancies in the one-chamber parliament by appointment and raise the number of its seats from 99 to 108 to attain equality between Moslems and Christians as envisaged by the peace plan. Christians have had a 6-to-5 edge in parliament since independence from France in 1943. The present parliament was elected in 1972 for a four-year term. The civil war, which broke out in 1975, has prevented elections and the house has repeatedly renewed its mandate. Government troops reunited civil war-divided Beirut Dec. 3 by deploying in the capital and its environs, as a first step in putting the peace accord into effect. The peaceful deployment followed withdrawal of the various militias from the capital to their respective areas of influence in north, east and south Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Topless Club's Gift Gets Cold Shoulder From Shelter
DOC.TEXT: A homeless mission turned down a $600 gift from a topless club, saying that accepting the donation would do more harm than good. ``We want people to be involved in giving, but I think the message you send has to be a clear message,'' said William Thompson, the Union Gospel Mission's executive director. ``It's kind of hypocritical for us to be teaching and preaching to our guys about moral responsibility and a the same time taking the benefits of people's moral irresponsibility.'' Workers at the Dallas Gentleman's Club said they had just wanted to do something nice. ``I just think that the spirit of giving ought to be offered to everybody,'' club owner Randy Dumas said. ``I guess we were just a little hurt that they looked down their noses at us.'' In a letter to the club, Thompson wrote: ``We sincerely appreciate your concern for the homeless in Dallas. However, the Union Gospel Mission ministers not only to the physical needs, but to the spiritual needs as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan To End State of War with China in May
DOC.TEXT: The Nationalist government will formally end in May a state of war it declared against the Chinese Communists in 1948, according to presidential spokesman Cheyne Chiu. Nationalist Chinese President Lee Teng-hui announced in his inaugural speech last May he would declare an end to the state of war, but he gave no date. On Saturday, Chiu said the state of war would end in May 1991. He told the state-run Broadcasting Corp. of China the move is expected to help efforts to reunify China and Taiwan. They have been separated since the Nationalists retreated to this island in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communists. Chiu said the Nationalists have no timetable to reunify China, but ending the state of war will reinforce the government's determination to achieve a peaceful reunification. He urged the Beijing government to respond favorably by renouncing its threat to use force to reunify China and Taiwan should other attempts fail. ``The Chinese Communists will never win the approval of the 20 million people here (for reunification) if they insist on using force to resolve the problem across the Taiwan Strait,'' he said. Both Nationalists and Communists regard Taiwan as a Chinese province. The Nationalists continue to regard themselves as China's legitimate government.

DOC.HEAD: Cellular Will Reach All Areas of Nation in 18 Months, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Cellular phone service should be available nationwide by mid-1992 now that federal authorities have issued at least one construction permit for systems in all urban and rural areas, an industry trade group said Sunday. The Federal Communications Commission on Friday issued 20 new permits, including Tunica County, Miss., and Kosciusko County, Ind., the only two areas of the country in which cellular systems had not been authorized, the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association said. ``We couldn't ask for a much better Christmas present,'' CTIA President Robert W. Maher said. ``One of our industry's most important goals is to provide ubiquitous service across America, so that if you're traveling, you can use your phone anywhere. Building these ... markets makes that dream a reality.'' Cellular also will be a boon to those living in rural areas, Maher added. The FCC has designated 306 metropolitan, or MSA, markets and 428 rural, or RSA, markets and said that two cellular operators may be licensed in each market. All of the nation's MSA markets, which cover about 75 percent of the population, has cellular service, the CTIA said. The 428 RSA markets cover only about 25 percent of the population but span about 80 percent of the nation's land mass. Of the 428 RSAs, about 150 have cellular service, the CTIA said. The FCC, through a lottery, awarded the last cellular licenses in December 1989. It now is in the process of awarding construction permits for the lottery winners, who then have 18 months to activate their systems. Friday's permit awards assured that by mid-1992, all areas of the nation should have at least one operating cellular system. The cellular industry also plans to introduce within 12 months to 18 months an automatic call delivery service that will allow cellular users to receive calls automatically, no matter where they are. Currently, callers seeking someone who has traveled away from his or her local calling area must know where that person is in order to complete a call. With automatic call delivery, a person ``roaming'' outside the home market will send out a locating signal to the closest cellular system whenever he or she turns on the cellular phone. Computers then will do the searching and service authorizations. ``If you're up in Chicago and I'm back in Washington and all I've got is your local Washington number, I'm going to be able to dial that Washington number ... and that phone call i going to find you ... anywhere in the United States,'' CTIA spokesman Norman Black said. But before ``seamless roaming'' can be introduced in all areas, the regional Bell companies will need to receive a waiver from a 1984 consent decree that limits what long-distance and computer services the Bell companies may provide. In September, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene Greene issued a limited waiver allowing Bell companies in some markets to introduce ``intersystem handoff'' so that callers traveling between some cities will not have to hang up and dial again as they pass from one cellular system to another.

DOC.HEAD: Welch Miners Fear Hard Times As Region's Last Mine Closes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th pvs, `The stark..' with details. Pick up 8th graf, `The local...'
DOC.TEXT: When Ivor Jones went into the coal mine in 1926, there were four pits operating in Maerdy, and 52 others in the surrounding Rhondda valleys. At 78, he saw the last one close this week, and 280 men lose their jobs. Twenty others accepted mining jobs elsewhere. ``It's a sad bloody moment, this pit closing,'' Jones said as the last shifts were being worked at the Maerdy colliery. ``I went to the soup kitchens when I was 9 years of age. I saw hard times and depressions. I'm afraid now that it's going to start all over again,'' he said. Work stopped on Thursday. On Friday, Maerdy's miners and their families marched to the pit behind a brass band, their lodge banner fluttering damply in the drizzle, to dedicate a plaque to their mine and a nearly vanished way of life. It was a quiet defeat for a town once known as ``little Moscow,'' where miners flew the red flag at the pit head in the 1920s. ``The stark reality is that 300 men, mostly with families, with an average age of 34, are losing their jobs at Christmas time,'' said the Rev. Norman Hadfield, a former miner who conducted a memorial service. Miners received severance pay based on their length of service, in some cases exceeding $60,000. The local district council and the government-sponsored Welsh Development Authority are already working on new industries for Maerdy, but the results may be years away. The WDA says it has created more than 700 jobs close to Maerdy, and a new business park has opened in Ferndale, two miles downstream. That hasn't lifted the gloom felt by some miners. ``There are no prospects for me in another job at the moment,'' said Mike L'Homme, who was losing his job after 10 years. ``Very few men have found new jobs to go to and families face a bleak time here because there isn't any work in the Rhondda,'' said Eric Price, a miner since 1963. Unemployment in Wales is 6.7 percent, compared to 6.0 percent in Britain as a whole, but it's two points higher in the mid-Glamorgan region, including the Rhondda valleys. South Wales has seen worse. In the general strike of 1926, the Trade Union Congress gave up after nine days; the miners stayed out from May until December, at last nearly starved back to work. In the 1930s, unemployment exceeded 70 percent in some valleys. ``When I was working up there, there wasn't even a road to the mine,'' said Jones, who started mining in 1926. ``You'd walk up the railroad track in all kinds of weather - hail, snow, whatever - then you went down in the pit soaking wet, and there was no protective clothing. ``And then if there was an accident, the men had to carry them down on a stretcher.'' Jones' son Alun, also a retired miner, sipped pints of bitter in the Miners' Institute as his father talked. ``That pit closing is ripping the guts out of me,'' the son said. In 1913, South Wales produced a third of the world's coal exports and had 485 working mines. The valleys also produced leaders: Arthur Horner, a founder of the National Union of Mineworkers, was a Maerdy man; Aneurin Bevan, a Labor Cabinet minister in the 1940s, and the Labor Party's current leader, Neil Kinnock, both came from nearby Tredegar. Mining employment peaked at 272,000 in 1920, and in 1923 the mines produced 52.25 million tons. By the mid-1930s, production and employment fell by more than half. As late as 1958 there were a dozen working mines in the Rhondda. Since 1969, there was only Maerdy. Maerdy is a grim little town at the head of the narrow valley of Rhondda Fach, or little Rhondda. At this time of year the sun slips below the ridge separating it from Rhondda Fawr before 3 p.m. Whatever wealth was made in Maerdy, little of it stayed. The only big building is the Miner's Institute, built in 1905. The basic home is a two-story stone row house, two windows wide, standing row on row up the western side of the valley. Backed against greening mountains of rubble, the town evokes ``The Angry Summer,'' a poem about the general strike by Idris Davies, born three valleys east in Rhymney: ``Great are the shadows over the Rhondda ``And the mansions built in the shires, ``Great are the fortunes made in Gwalia ``And the promontories of slag.''

DOC.HEAD: Oman Urges Dialogue Before Any Military Stike
DOC.TEXT: Oman pressed Sunday for a dialogue with Iraq before any military strike, but one official insisted the small state was not breaking with its Persian Gulf allies. Official sources at the summit of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council said the Omanis were contending more peace avenues should be explored before using military force. The three-day gathering opened Saturday. ``This does not mean that the Omanis are opposed to the consensus that the Iraqi leader should be disciplined forcefully,'' said one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The Omanis are partners in the multinational force assembled in eastern Saudi Arabia to deal with the Iraqis if necessary.'' The U.N. Security Council has authorized use of military force to dislodge Iraq if it has not withdrawn from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, also members of the council, have insisted there will be no dialogue with Baghdad before the Iraqis pull out of Kuwait unconditionally and the ruling al-Sabah family is reinstated. The Kuwait government-in-exile has indicated it would be willing to discuss oil, money and land disputes with Iraq after a full withdrawal, but has said it will not cede any territory. ``The GCC leaders are set against rewarding the aggressor with any concessions,'' Qatar Foreign Minister Mubarak al-Khater said earlier. ``They will not engage in any dialogue or hold any negotiations with the Iraqi leader before his forces are completely withdrawn from Kuwait.'' Leaders at the summit were King Fhad of Saudi Arabia; Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah of Kuwait; Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani of Qatar; Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates and Sultan Qaboos of Oman. The sixth member, Bahrain, was represented by Prime Minister Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa. Alliance sources said Oman warned that the region was headed for war, and urged that dialogue and economic sanctions be given a chance. Kuwait at one point urged its Gulf Cooperation Council allies to break off diplomatic relations with Iraq, but the other members said it was important to maintain lines of communication. The alliance countries, whose economic and security group was born in 1981, have a joint force of 10,000 troops based in northeastern Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Fatalities in Operation Desert Shield
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-eight American military personnel have died since Operation Desert Shield began Aug. 7, most of them in air crashes and accidents. Twenty-one drowned when a ferry sank off Israel. Two were suicides. Here is a list of the fatal incidents: ---

Dec. 22 - A soldier was killed in Saudi Arabia when the truck he was riding in overturned. Dec. 22 - Twenty-one sailors from the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga drowned in the Mediterranean off the Israeli port of Haifa when the boat returning them to the vessel from Christmas shore leave capsized in rough seas. Twenty bodies were recovered; another man was listed as missing and presumed dead. It was the single biggest death toll from an incident related to Desert Shield. Dec. 10 - A Marine died in northeastern Saudi Arabia of a presumed ruptured brain aneurysm. A Marine died from a presumed heart attack on the assault ship USS Iwo Jima after physical fitness training in Bahrain. Dec. 9 - An Army private was killed in Saudi Arabia when the tractor-trailer water supply truck he was driving overturned. Dec. 5 - A 20-year-old private with the Army's 20th engineer brigade was killed when he was hit by a truck at a desert base in Saudi Arabia. Dec. 4 - A Tennessee National Guard lieutenant colonel was found dead from a gunshot in his tent in Saudi Arabia. U.S. spokesmen said he shot himself. Dec. 1 - An airman with the 4th Tactical Fighter Wing's engineering squadron was killed in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia. Nov. 30 - A Marine corporal with the 4th Marine Expeditionary Brigade died of an apparent heart attack aboard the USS Shreveport in the Persian Gulf. Nov. 24 - A soldier from the 101st Combat Support Group was killed when the truck he was riding collided with a civilian car in Saudi Arabia. Nov. 17 - A soldier from the 101st Aviation Brigade was killed in a truck accident in Saudi Arabia. Nov. 9 - A member of the 3rd Marine regiment in northeastern Saudi Arabia was killed in his sleep when a rifle was accidentally discharged. Nov. 8 - A soldier was found dead in a shower in Saudi Arabia, but an initial investigation ruled out foul play. Nov. 7 - A 1st Cavalry Division soldier died from injuries sustained trying to free a truck stuck in the Saudi desert. Oct. 30 - Ten sailors were killed when a steam line ruptured in the boiler room of the assault carrier USS Iwo Jima in the Persian Gulf. Oct. 30 - A Marine was killed when his vehicle overturned in the Saudi desert. Oct. 10 - The two-man crew of an Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber were killed in a crash during a low-level training flight in Saudi Arabia. Oct. 8 - Two fliers of the Alabama Air National Guard were killed when their Phantom reconnaisance jet crashed in Saudi Arabia. Oct. 8 - Two UH-1 helicopters from the assault carrier USS Okinawa, carrying eight Marines, vanished during a night training flight in the northern Arabian Sea. Sept. 30 - The two-man crew of an Air Force F-15 Eagle fighter were killed when the plane crashed during a low-level exercise in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 26 - A sergeant from the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 20 - A soldier with the 82nd Airborne Division was killed in a vehicle accident in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 14 - An officer from the 24th Infantry Division was killed when his vehicle crashed in Saudi Arabia. Sept. 11 - A machinists' mate died of natural causes aboard the USS Lasalle in the Persian Gulf. Aug. 29 - A C-5A Galaxy transport aircraft loaded with supplies for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf crashed shortly after takeoff from Ramstein air base in Germany, killing 13 crewmen. Aug. 21 - An electrician's mate aboard the missile cruiser USS Antietam was electrocuted while working on the ship's ventilation system. Aug. 12 - An Air Force sergeant died when he was hit by a military truck on a darkened runway in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Population Growth Hits New Postwar Low
DOC.TEXT: Statistics that show Japan's population growth declining to a postwar low are likely to sharpen fears that lagging birth rates are weakening the nation's economy. Preliminary figures released Friday from Japan's 1990 census show the nation grew by only 2.1 percent from 1985 to 1990. The 3.4 percent growth from 1980-85 was the previous postwar low. The Oct. 1 census counted 123,622,541 people in Japan. The country is still the world's seventh most populous, but it has one of the world's slowest growth rates. Over the past year, the country has been flooded with magazine, newspaper and television reports that speak of a ``baby shock.'' Officials express fear that with fewer children, the nation will eventually have trouble supporting the elderly, a growing percentage of the population. Business leaders say industry is already beginning to feel a labor shortage. Birth rates in Japan have been declining since the introduction of modern birth control after World War II, according to Dr. Makoto Atoh, director of the Health and Welfare Ministry's department of population policy studies. A housing shortage, high land prices, rising ages at marriage, and the soaring costs of education and child-rearing have contributed to the declining rate, he said. ``We think the major cause for the decline is the rising percentage of singles and the rising age of marriage,'' Atoh said. Health and Welfare Ministry figures show that 20 percent of people in their late 20s were single in 1975, but 37 percent in that age group were single last year. Most women believe the high cost of educating children is the biggest obstacle to having more, said Dr. Naohiro Ogawa, deputy director of the Nippon University population research institute, and the consultant for a recent survey by Mainichi newspaper. Another factor is cramped housing conditions and the astronomical prices of new homes. Mechanization in the home, expanded education and job opportunities have led an increasing number of women out of the home. Some say the refusal of men to change their roles in the home discourages large families. ``Japanese men don't share housekeeping. All the burden is on the shoulder of women at home, so it's impossible to have more children,'' said Mariko Mitsui, a Tokyo city assemblywoman. A government policy group has considered revamping maternity leaves, changing housing policies, and improving child care as measures to get women to have more children. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, a governing Liberal Democratic Party leader and a likely future prime minister, caused an uproar in June when he was quoted as blaming the shrinking birth rates on the expanded opportunities for higher education for women. Hashimoto later denied making the remark. Four out of five women questioned in the Mainichi survey said they opposed government intervention to boost the birth rate, Ogawa said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian President Urges Resistance To Soviet Direct Rule
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis has told the pro-independence Sajudis movement that direct Soviet rule may be imposed, and he urged it to prepared to resist, Tass reported Sunday. The official Soviet news agency quoted Landsbergis as telling Sajudis-backed lawmakers on Saturday ``there are signs that rule of this kind has already been introduced surreptitiously.'' The report did not say what those signs were, although leaders of independence movements in the three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have contended in recent weeks that the Kremlin is preparing to crack down on them. Tass quoted Landsbergis, also the Sajudis leader, as urging the lawmakers to ``develop a detailed program for resistance if the Soviet Union introduces an overtly occupationist form of rule in Lithuania.'' He said attempts were being made to impose a new Union Treaty on Lithuania ``through threats of bloodshed and use of violence'' and that it was essential to prepare means of ``resistance, self-defense.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is under increasing pressure from hard-liners to introduce a state of emergency and rule by decree in areas troubled by ethnic or political conflict. Last week, he told the Congress of People's Deputies, the national parliament, that he would not hesitate to do so in regions where conflicts threaten security or people's lives. At the same time, Gorbachev is seeking approval for the new Union Treaty regrouping the 15 Soviet republics in a loose federation with the central government. Landsbergis reiterated Lithuania's refusal to sign the document. ``Lithuania has already made its choice and will remain true to it,'' Tass quoted him as saying. Lithuania declared independence on March 11. Since then, the other 14 republics have also declared some form of independence or autonomy from the central government.

DOC.HEAD: Constitution to End Military Rule in Guinea Looks Headed for OK
DOC.TEXT: A referendum on a new consitution that would end military rule in this West African nation appeared headed for approval in a vote Sunday. However, critics say the document will allow the military to keep too much power. Several other African countries are also carrying out major political reform in the wake of the pro-democratic revolutions last year in Eastern Europe. Electoral officials said initial results indicated the referendum was winning approval. Many areas reported up to 98 percent voting in favor of the document. Final results were expected Monday. The document provides for the military to hand over power to two political parties, but only after a five-year transition during which a military-picked council would rule. Opponents have criticized the lengthy transition period, the makeup of the council, and constitutional provisions allowing only two political parties. The government says the two-party provision would prevent parties from forming along tribal lines. It said the long transition period is needed for an orderly transfer of power. Guinea has been hit this year by strikes by government workers demanding bigger salaries, university graduates unable to find work and students wanting larger government grants. Last month, police fired on protesting students, killing two and wounding three. Guineans suffered years of brutal repression under Sekou Toure. He ruled from 1958, when Guinea became independent from France, until his death of a heart attack in 1984. The military then staged a coup and Brig. Gen. Lansana Conte took over as president. Conte's government is accused of corruption and oppression, including detentions without trial and torture of political detainees, according to the London-based human rights group Amnesty International. Guinea's population was estimated at 6.3 million in 1987, but that does not include at least 2 million Guineans who fled during Sekou Toure's rule and remain in exile. Guinea is rich in minerals but among the poorest countries in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Blackout Drill Darkens Half of Baghdad
With AM-Gulf-US, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Authorities cut power to eastern Baghdad on Sunday night, plunging half the capital into darkness for 15 minutes in a blackout drill testing the city's ability to cope with air raids. Air raid sirens blared at 9 p.m. and the power was switched off to all of Baghdad east of the Tigris River. The only light was the glow cast by gas flares from the tall tower of a refinery on the river's west bank. It was the first practice blackout, but senior officials said Saturday plans were being made for such drills in all the major population centers. Lt. Col. Wa'il Abid Hamudi, operations director at the Civil Defense Department, told state television such drills will test Iraq's ability to cope with air raids if it is attacked. Hamudi asked the population to comply strictly with instructions given by news media for carrying out the blackout. Residents were told to turn off outdoor lights and use thick curtains inside to prevent light from being spotted by enemy planes. Motorists were advised to turn off headlights and park when they hear sirens. Street lights would be switched off and store owners were told to disconnect their neon signs. He had said the drill would last for only one minute. However, instead of relying on people to switch off lights, the power was simply cut to eastern Baghdad on Sunday night for 15 minutes after the siren sounded. Iraq has stepped up civil defense preparations since the U.N. Security Council set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi to withdraw from Kuwait or face military action. An evacuation drill was held in Baghdad on Friday to move about 1.5 million people from the eastern half of the capital to havens outside the city. Officials said similar plans were under way in other Iraqi cities.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Defense Minister: Iraq Ready To Crush Any Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Turkish politician's meeting with Saddam, Turkish military preparations. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's defense minister said Sunday that his country is ready to crush any military attack, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. INA said Lt. Gen. Saadi Tuma Abbas was responding to comments by U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who said multinational forces in Saudi Arabia will be ready to strike if Iraq does not pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. ``The U.S. defense minister and those who support him will see how the earth will be burned under their feet not only in Iraq but also in Saudi Arabia and other Arab gulf countries,'' Abbas was quoted as saying. Cheney told troops in Saudi Arabia on Saturday that reinforcements expected to arrive soon would give the United States the force needed to liberate Kuwait. Cheney, on a Middle East tour with Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, repeated the claim in Egypt on Sunday. Any U.S. strike is expected after Jan. 15, the deadline set by the U.N. Security Council for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face possible attack. The United States is the largest contributor to a 28-nation military force of about 480,000 troops sent to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region after Kuwait was seized. The multinational forces face an estimated 510,000 Iraqi troops in the occupied emirate and southern Iraq. Abbas said Islamic holy warriors in Saudi Arabia would join in the fight against King Fahd's ``treason in the eastern area of Saudi Arabia.'' Iraq has appealed to Moslems worldwide for support in its confrontation with the West, saying Fahd betrayed Islam by inviting foreign troops to help defend his country, home of Islam's holiest shrines. INA, monitored in Cyprus, also reported that George Habash, leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, called on ``all Arab masses and their revolutionary fighter groups to mobilize to turn Saudi Arabia into a cemetery for the American invaders.'' The Syrian-backed Front was kicked out of Iraq 11 years ago because of a split between Baghdad and Damascus, but it reopened offices in the Iraqi capital on Saturday. Turkish politician Erdal Inonu said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told him on Sunday that Iraq increased its forces along its border with Turkey in response to Ankara's request for NATO air units, Turkey's semi-official news agency Anatolia reported. It quoted Inonu, leader of the main opposition Social Democrat Populist Party, as telling a news conference in Baghdad after a two-hour meeting with Saddam that Saddam expressed disappointed about a recent reinforcement of Turkish forces at the border. Saddam claimed the Turkish military moves were imposed by the United States, according to Inonu. Saddam was quoted as saying Iraq had no intention to attack Turkey nor any ambitions toward Turkish territory. The Istanbul daily Hurriyet, meanwhile, reported Sunday that the Turkish armed forces would go on alert as of Jan. 2. It said several air units, including F-16, F-4 and F-5 fighters, were in the process of being transferred to four military air bases in southeast Turkey from the western and central Anatolian air bases. Hurriyet said air forces personnel were banned from taking any leaves starting in January.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Against Dictatorship Starts Critical Week For Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to ADD background on Khrushchev, RECAST lead to CLARIFY that dictatorship is feared, sted already in place; pickup graf 9 pvs `As the...' ^By BRIAN FRIEDMAN
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people rallied Sunday to denounce moves they fear could bring dictatorship to the Kremlin. Their protest came at the start of a critical week in which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seeks parliamentary approval for stronger presidential powers. Signs carried by some in the crowd of 1,500 people supported Eduard Shevardnadze, who resigned Thursday as foreign minister to protest the growing influence of hard-liners and what he said was a coming dictatorship. ``Shevardnadze is with us. Gorbachev is against us. Shevardnadze, stay with us!'' pleaded one sign, held aloft on a broken hockey stick. Alexander Obolensky, a radical member of the Congress of People's Deputies, said reformers such as Shevardnadze and Alexander N. Yakovlev have been forced into the background by hard-line Communists. Yakovlev retired in August from his post in the Communist Party leadership. ``Shevardnadze, trying to protect the intrigues of our president, sacrificed desperately his political career,'' Obolensky said at the rally. ``We want to ask you directly, Mikhail Sergeyevich,'' Obolensky said, addressing Gorbachev, ``you have pushed aside democrats, you surrendered your faithful supporter, Yakovlev. You lost Shevardnadze. Who are you going to be with?'' ``You are losing your allies,'' he said. ``Remember the fate of Khrushchev, the reformer. Don't expect us to bow our heads obediently like in 1964!'' Khrushchev was ousted that year and replaced by Leonid I. Brezhnev, who reversed many reforms. As the Congress begins the second week of its parliamentary session Monday, it is expected to begin preliminary voting on the constitutional amendments to strengthen Gorbachev's presidency. Gorbachev wants direct control over a reorganized executive branch of government to deal with a worsening economy and a fragmenting union. He also is expected to make changes in the leadership before the week is out, including naming a vice president. On Saturday, the deputies heard KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov deliver a speech that brought back some of the chill of the Cold War. Kryuchkov said the CIA is gathering information on workers' movements in the Soviet Union ``for its purposeful masterminding'' and funding of ``anti-Soviet formations'' such as radio stations that attack the Soviet Union. He also lashed out at pro-independence groups in the 15 Soviet republics, saying they have armed 26,000 fighters. He said foreigners were trying to topple the Soviet government. ``Today, if we undertake decisive actions to restore order, we have to accept the fact that there could be bloodshed,'' Kryuchkov said. Maria Denisenko, a radical member of the Russian legislature, attacked Kryuchkov's speech as ``tragic'' at a time when the United States and other Western nations were sending aid to the Soviet Union. ``The KGB chief clearly showed us that he is going to defend socialist gains, and he won't stop at anything, including bloodshed,'' she said. ``If the moment comes, the whole nation should rise up to defend democracy!'' The crowd in the small square opposite Moscow City Hall cheered. Congress deputy and crusading magazine editor Vitaly Korotich, who did not address the rally, said in an interview that Kryuchkov's speech had little relevance. ``I think that the KGB, of course, always needs an enemy. I think if the KGB collapsed, the CIA would die of starvation, and vice versa,'' Korotich said. But Kryuchkov was not the only Soviet official talking tough on Saturday. Gorbachev issued a decree declaring that separatist actions by Turkish Christians and Russians in the southwestern republic of Moldavia were illegal. In a presidential decree, he gave Moldavia 10 days to dissolve a new national guard and to reconsider a law that made Moldavian, which is similar to Romanian, the republic's official language. On Sunday in Kishinev, the capital of Moldavia, a rally of ``reconciliation'' organized by the Communist Party ended in a brawl after some people shouted at participants, ``Invaders, go home!'' and tried to seize the microphones, the Tass news agency reported. Soviet television showed shoving matches in the crowd, and Tass said police intervened to restore order. Afterward, opponents of the rally marched to the local party headquarters and shouted anti-Communist slogans, Tass said. Moldavia, which borders Romania, has been hit by ethnic tension during its push for independence from the Soviet Union. The Gagauz, a group of about 150,000 Turkish Christians, declared a new republic in southern Moldavia. In eastern Moldavia, more than 300,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have declared a new republic along the Dniester River.

DOC.HEAD: New Soviet Company Dances `Nutcracker'
DOC.TEXT: The youthful Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company is performing a most charming version of ``The Nutcracker.'' The Moscow import adds another variation to this season's New York City Ballet and Joffrey Ballet performances and American Ballet Theater's rendition of ``The Nutcracker'' on television Christmas Day. Yuri Grigorovich, artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, announced his new company in October. After performances in Moscow, the company has been touring America since Nov. 23. Its version of ``The Nutcracker'' runs through Dec. 30 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Saturday night cast was the same as at Wednesday's opening except for Drosselmeyer, the magician. Oleg Dedogriuk was a spry, brisk dancer in white wig in this version, not a creaky oldster. This company doesn't have any aging members, the 60 dancers being 19 to 25. It also doesn't have any children. Small dancers dance the children. And when Drosselmeyer walks in with a nutcracker doll, it's really Tamara Glasova under his arm, wearing red and a mask with a wide mouth. Marie - called Clara in the original in 1892 - is Oksana Konobeyeva, who has a sweet face and fine form. She can't hold balance unsupported so she moved quickly off poses that end on one toe or held the pose graciously when supported by Dmitry Tuboltsev as the Nutcracker Prince. Tuboltsev, small and slim, has the poise of a dancer noble. He jumped high and landed lightly and securely. He is clearly a dancer to watch. Many members of this company are expected to enter the Bolshoi Ballet. The Mouse King, Maxim Knish, also was a fine dancer. Grigorovich choreographed the mice-toy soldiers' fight less like a fight than a dance. When the Mouse King was wounded and carried out, he twitched his claws delightfully, raising childish laughs all over the auditorium. There's no toy Nutcracker and no Sugar Plum Fairy here. Marie does all the leading ballerina dancing. There are five ethnic couples who have duets, a form beloved of choreographers making full-length ballets to Tchaikovsky music. Here, they're Spanish, Indian, Chinese, Russian and a shepherd and shepherdess from France who dance pulling a gray sheep on wheels between them. They all were very good. And the scenery, the Christmas tree becoming larger and white, was surprisingly elaborate for a touring company. A Russian conductor, Alexander Lavrenyuk, led the orchestra.

DOC.HEAD: Aristide Officially Declared Winner of Presidential Election
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a leftist who has championed the cause of Haiti's poor, was declared winner Sunday of the country's first fully free elections. With an estimated 50.l per cent of the votes tallied, Aristide led with with 66.7 percent of the total, according to the Electoral Council. An estimated 75 per cent of more than two million registered voters had cast their ballots in general elections Dec. 16. Runners-up Marc Bazin and Louis Dejoie Jr. had 15.4 percent and 5 percent respectively. Silvio Claude had just over 3 percent, and the seven other candidates received the rest of the vote. ``You have made a sacrifice to show the world the true face of Haiti,'' Aristide told the nation, speaking Creole, immediately after the announcement on state-run radio. He spoke from the office of his center for homeless children. The four major runners-up had all conceded defeat by Saturday, after partial results showed Aristide had won by a landslide. ``Things must change, things must change for everyone,'' he said, repeating the words of Pope Jean-Paul II. His March 1983 visit to Haiti initiated the official Roman Catholic opposition to the Duvalier dictatorship that ended three years later during a popular uprising. Legislative and local election results have not as yet been announced. Runoff elections in those races will be held Jan. 20.
