Most analysts believe the National Front for Change and Democracy, the left-wing coalition which nominated Aristide, will dominate the two-chamber National Assembly and form a parliamentary bloc with Dejoie's National Agricultural and Industrial Party. The National Assembly would thus have a pro-Aristide majority. According to the 1987 Constitution, the president must choose his prime minister from among the members of the parliamentary majority. The president is head of state, while the prime minister runs the government. From the pulpit of his church St. Jean Bosco, Aristide had won fame for his defense of the poor and attacks of repressive government. On Sept. 11, 1988, thugs torched his church, killing at least 12 and wounding 70. Aristide was excluded from his Salesian Father religious order in December 1988, allegedly for fomenting violence. After a pro-Aristide rally Dec. 5, an unknown assailant lobbed a grenade into a crowd, killing seven and injuring more than 50. Aristide will inaugurated Feb. 9 on the fifth anniversary of the fall of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, whose family ruled Haiti for over three decades.

DOC.HEAD: New York Drug Kingpin and Associates Convicted
DOC.TEXT: A drug kingpin who ran what investigators say was an especially violent operation was convicted in federal court Sunday of drug conspiracy, racketeering and money laundering. Prosecutors say Ricardo Melendez ran a gang that used violence to maintain discipline within its ranks and raked in as much as $10 million a month peddling heroin and cocaine in some of Brooklyn's poorest neighborhoods. The court heard from witnesses who said they had double-crossed Melendez andhis top lieutenants and paid for it with maimings and mutilations - ice-pick stabbings, teeth pulled out, fingers chopped off. Melendez, 30, remained in federal custody to await sentencing, when he will face mandatory life in prison. No date was set. ``We're very happy with the verdict,'' said U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney. ``This was a very important drug organization, most of whom will now be locked behind bars for most of their lives.'' Melendez's lawyer, Lawrence Hochheiser, had argued the government failed to prove any conspiracy and maintained the defendants couldn't run a complex organization. Seven members of Melendez's organization, including his No. 2 man, also were convicted Sunday of various charges including murder, kidnapping and drug conspiracy. The federal jury deliberated five days before handing up the verdicts. The three-month trial before U.S. District Judge Arthur Spatt included testimony from witnesses who told of physical intimidation, violence and riches. One juror was dismissed when deliberations were to begin after he reported receiving a threatening note at his home. The FBI was investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Surinamese Army Chief Announces Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Suriname's former military ruler, Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, announced his resignation Sunday as army commander. The Dutch government warned of a possible military coup in its former colony. In a Dutch TV interview by telephone from Paramaribo, capital of Suriname, Bouterse said his resignation was an act of defiance toward President Ramsewak Shankar. ``I'm no longer willing to take orders from this kind of a joker who exposes the dignity of his nation to ridicule,'' Bouterse said. Shankar was chosen president of the small, mineral-rich nation on South America's northeastern coast in free elections in November 1987. His installation in January 1988 ended eight years of dictatorship by Bouterse. In The Hague, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said, ``The Dutch government hopes Bouterse realizes that a coup ... will have a detrimental effect on development aid.'' Suriname, a nation of 400,000 people, has been heavily dependent on Dutch aid. It gained independence from the Netherlands in 1975 and was governed as a Western-style democracy until Bouterse seized power in a February 1980 coup. Bouterse did not say when his resignation would take effect or who would replace him. According to Dutch Television, the Surinamese army was placed on alert, heightening speculation about a possible Bouterse coup attempt. However, the television also quoted a Surinamese army statement as saying it would continue ``reconcilatory overtures'' made by Bouterse toward the Shankar government. The Dutch have been at odds in the past with Bouterse, whose troops shot to death 15 prominent opposition figures in 1983. The deaths prompted suspension of a $1.1 billion Dutch aid package to Suriname.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Wave Spreads, Record Warm In East, Floods In Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Still more record lows were established Sunday, many below zero, while the East Coast had record highs and heavy rain caused flooding in the Southeast. Lows of 20 below zero or colder were reported in Idaho, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, Nebraska, South Dakota, North Dakota, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin, the National Weather Service reported. Temperatures reached 30 below zero in Colorado, Wyoming, South Dakota, North Dakota and Minnesota. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 39 below zero at Craig, Colo. The low of 19 at Bakersfield, Calif., was an all-time record. The previous record, of 20, was tied Saturday. The low of 7 below zero at Albuquerque, N.M., was the city's first subzero reading on record for December. The low of 11 at Las Vegas, Nev., also was a record for December. Other records were 29 below zero at Alamosa, Colo.; 6 below at Amarillo, Texas; 17 below at Colorado Springs, Colo.; 16 below at Denver; 9 below at Goodland, Kan.; 17 below at Grand Junction, Colo.; 30 below at Huron, S.D.; 7 at Medford, Ore.; 26 at Phoenix; 29 below at Pocatello, Idaho; 25 below at Pueblo, Colo.; 9 below at Reno, Nev.; 36 at San Diego, Calif.; 27 below at Scottsbluff, Neb.; 28 below at Sioux Falls, S.D.; and 21 at Tucson, Ariz. Temperatures began to moderate a bit over the Great Plains region, with readings in the single digits and teens by early afternoon. The temperature at Scottsbluff, Neb., finally rose above zero for the first time in 97 hours. But brisk westerly wind blew over the north-central states and wind chill readings included 44 below zero at Rock Springs, Wyo., and 42 below zero at Watertown, S.D. Ahead of the cold front marking the leading edge of the arctic air, unseasonably warm weather extended from the eastern Gulf Coast into New England. Brisk southerly wind helped temperatures warm into the 60s as far north as southern New Hampshire, with readings in the 70s along the mid-Atlantic Coast. Record highs were 64 at Albany, N.Y.; 64 at Allentown, Pa.; 69 at Baltimore; 61 at Beckley, W.Va.; 65 at Boston; 58 at Burlington, Vt.; 65 at Concord, N.H.; 59 at Hartford, Conn.; 67 at Newark, N.J.; 77 at Norfolk, Va.; 66 at Roanoke, Va.; 64 at Scranton, Pa.; 64 at Wilmington, Del.; and 58 at Worcester, Mass. Rain and snow fell along the arctic cold front. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms developing along the front extended from extreme southeastern Louisiana to central Mississippi. Showers developing along and ahead of the front prevailed from northeastern Mississippi across the central Appalachians to New England. Showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in the Southeast late Saturday into Sunday morning, causing flooding that forced evacuations in parts of Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky. Heavier rainfall for the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST included 1.65 inches at Biloxi, Miss.; and 1.17 inches at Centreville, Ala. Heavier rainfall for the 24 hours up to 1 p.m. EST included more than three inches at Chattanooga, Tenn., (3.34) and nearly three inches at Knoxville, Tenn., (2.74). Behind the cold front, a mixture of freezing rain, freezing drizzle, sleet and snow fell from Louisiana to New York state. Light snow fell from Arkansas through Missouri and Illinois to Indiana. A winter storm watch was posted for Monday for parts of northern Vermont, upstate New York and the northern and western mountains of Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Victims of Ferry Disaster Remembered at Memorial Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 5th `The bodies...' to UPDATE with Dover Air Base spokesman saying bodies expected to arrive 10 a.m. EST Monday. Pickup 6th pvs `Capt. Joseph...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV2,3,5,6
DOC.TEXT: Crewmen of the U.S. aircraft carrier Saratoga bade farewell Sunday to 21 drowned comrades with tears, salvos of rifle fire and the Navy hymn ``Eternal Father.'' The shipboard memorial service was attended by about 1,200 of the Saratoga's crew, including most of the 81 sailors and Navy airmen who survived the fatal capsize of the chartered Israeli ferry early Saturday. On a table by the podium, 20 white sailors' caps and one chief petty officer's hat were arranged, symbolizing the lives lost. Israeli navy divers recovered the 20th body on Sunday near the submerged ferry, Haifa police said. Searches continued for the body of the 21st victim, declared missing and presumed drowned. The bodies were later flown aboard a military transport jet to the Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. They were expected to arrive 10 a.m. EST Monday, a base spokesman said. Capt. Joseph S. Mobley, commanding officer of the Saratoga, told reporters that the Navy had concluded with ``utmost confidence'' that the missing man had perished in the tragedy. ``He was definitely on the ferry at the time of the accident, he was definitely not rescued,'' Mobley said. ``He is not on the ship, he is not ashore.'' The ferry Tuvia capsized Saturday shortly after midnight as it was carrying 102 American seamen to the Saratoga from a Christmas shore leave. The ship is anchored about a mile off Israel's northern port of Haifa. The mourners gathered in one of the Saratoga's huge aircraft hangars. Through the open doors, Navy helicopters could been seen crisscrossing over the Mediterranean in search of the missing body. Two sailors dropped a wreath into the metal-gray sea in honor of the victims, and a detachment of seven Marines fired a 21-gun salute in three rifle salvos. Some of the sailors wiped tears from their eyes as a choir sang ``America the Beautiful'' and ``Eternal Father.'' Mobley addressed his remarks to the families of the dead. ``There are no words that can express the heartfelt sorrow of this entire 5,000-man ship,'' he said. Later, he told reporters: ``We have suffered a very great tragedy. Every man on this mighty ship has had his heart in his throat, tears in his eyes and a knot in his stomach since that event.'' The Saratoga task force, based at Mayport Naval Air Station in Florida, includes the destroyer Sampson, cruiser South Carolina and combat stores ship Sirius. It has a crew of 6,200 men. The ships anchored off Haifa on Thursday for the holidays, with shore leaves beginning Friday. Some wives and girlfriends who flew to Israel to be with their men were taken to the Saratoga by helicopter for the memorial service. The Saratoga and its escort ships were in the Red Sea as part of the naval buildup in the Gulf following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The accident was the deadliest involving U.S. servicemen in Operation Desert Shield, and it raised the number of Americans who have died to 78. Among the mourners Sunday were U.S. Ambassador William Brown; Admiral Nick Gee, commander of the Saratoga battle group; Haifa Mayor Aryeh Gurel; Israeli Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, and Israel's navy commander, Gen. Micha Ram. After the ceremony, Mobley talked to reporters and denied Israeli media reports that one of the victims had been handcuffed after being arrested ashore for drunkenness. ``That is totally false, totally false,'' Mobley said. ``There was not a man on that ship who was handcuffed or restrained because we are fully aware of the consequences of such an action.'' He added: ``I want to assure everyone, particularly the families, that we would not do such a thing.'' Reports in the Israeli press Sunday said one man was restrained by handcuffs when he became hysterical after he was rescued from the water. Three investigations by Haifa police, the Israeli Port Authority and the U.S. Navy have been launched into the sinking of the 57-foot, double-deck Tuvia about 200 yards from the Saratoga. Survivors reported that waves of about three to four feet had been pouring water over the stern and that two larger waves then swamped the ferry. Israeli officials said that a number of sailors had gathered in the back of the ferry in anticipation of getting off and may have destabilized the craft. Nineteen bodies were retrieved Saturday, including six brought up by Israelidivers from the Tuvia. Three dozen sailors were taken to hospitals, but most have been released.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officials Demands Emergency Measures To Handle Immigrant Wave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with immigration minister's comments, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TLV1
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials said Sunday that emergency efforts are needed to accommodate an influx of Soviet Jews, who the immigration minister said are ``raining from the sky'' in record numbers. In southern Beersheba, immigrants set up a tent camp to protest lack of housing. Other Israelis there staged a demonstration to urge that mobile homes for immigrants not be put near their prosperous neighborhood. About 5,500 Soviet Jews reached Israel in a special airlift from Thursday through Saturday, with an additional 1,500 arriving Sunday. State television broadcast footage of the unprecedented flood of immigrants being processed at Ben Gurion International Airport outside Tel Aviv. ``I've never seen anything like this here,'' said Shifra Oren, a longtime volunteer at the terminal. Immigration Minister Yitzhak Peretz said the influx of newcomers had forced authorities to resort to emergency housing solutions for the first time since the immigration wave began in mid-1989. He said about a third of this weekend's arrivals were housed in hotels. Officials attributed the upsurge to fears of political instability and the economic crisis in the Soviet Union, and to improved transit through Eastern European countries. ``The trick is to get the Jews out as soon as quickly as possible,'' Seymour Reich, outgoing chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said after stepping off a plane. Reich said the urgency was partly out of concerns triggered by Thursday's resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. The resignation has aggravated fears of growing unrest in the Soviet Union. Jewish groups planned to ask the Bush administration ``to use every means possible at their command to bring the Jews out,'' Reich added. The sense of urgency was pointed up by a government waiver of the usual ban on Friday evening and Saturday flights, the Jewish sabbath. Israel's national carrier El Al was ordered to use every plane available to ferry the Jews from Eastern Europe. Simcha Dinitz, chairman of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency that handles immigrant transportation, said the rate was expected to increase to a regular influx of 1,500 Soviets daily. Officials expect more than 30,000 Soviets in December, bringing this year's immigration total to 200,000. That includes all Jewish immigrants. Israel expects about 1 million Soviets by the end of 1992. Uri Gordon, chief of the Jewish Agency's Immigration Department, urged the government to declare a state of emergency. ``We witness a real drama of a people in migration. But we should remember we will be tested by absorption. We have to declare a state of emergency in the country and create a new set of priorities,'' Gordon said. ``We should immediately freeze housing prices and each one in the Israeli society personally has to help. ... The government alone won't solve the problem.'' In the Negev desert town of Beersheba, where thousands of Soviets have settled, eight new immigrant families raised a tent camp in the southern town of Beersheba to dramatize the housing crunch. ``The allowance they receive is not enough to rent an apartment,'' protest spokesman Ilya Schneider said. He said a two-bedroom apartment in the least expensive Beersheba neighborhood costs $400 a month. An immigrant family of three receives $9,000 a year in government allowance to cover rent, food, clothing, education and transportation expenses. ``There are cases of four, five families renting one apartment, and this leads to problems ... arguments and even fist fights,'' Schneider said. Beersheba city officials said protesters refused to sign rent contracts, fearing they will run out of money and have no place to live. Israelis in Beersheba's well-to-do Neve Noy area demonstrated to protest government plans to set up 7,000 mobile homes for immigrants near their neighborhood. The housing crisis has been made worse by slow building starts. Work has begun on only about 17,000 of 45,000 housing units planned to be started in 1990, officials report.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Hints Talks Off If South Holds Military Exercises
DOC.TEXT: North Korea indicated Sunday it will call off the fourth round of premiers' talks with South Korea if the South goes ahead with annual military exercises with the United States. The official Workers (Communist) Party newspaper Rodong Shinmun said, ``If the South Korean ruling quarters stage the `Team Spirit' war game next year again together with the U.S. imperialist aggressors, they will face a strong denunciation within and without as the wrecker of the North-South dialogues.'' The commentary was broadcast in part by the North's Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo. It called the decision to hold the annual exercises in 1991 ``a deliberate criminal act totally denying the North-South dialogues.'' North Korea broke off talks in the past during the exercises. The commentary said the exercises brought the situation on the Korean peninsula ``to the brink of war.'' In the highest-level talks ever between Communist North and capitalist South, the two premiers began meeting in September to discuss easing tensions and steps toward reunification. A fourth round of talks is scheduled Feb. 25-28 in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. The Koreas were divided in 1945. The North invaded the South in 1950, starting a three-year war.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Announces Cease-Fire for Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with British official reax to cease-fire; pickup graf 6 pvs `In Northern...'
DOC.TEXT: The leadership of the Irish Republican Army on Sunday announced a three-day Christmas cease-fire, the first in 15 years. Britain's Cabinet minister for Northern Ireland, Peter Brooke, welcomed the cease-fire. He said he hoped it pointed to a lasting peace in 1991. The decision to suspend IRA military activity from midnight Sunday to midnight Wednesday was announced in a statement issued in Dublin and released in Belfast. ``We have instructed all active service units to suspend all offensive military action in the British-occupied area for a period of three days from midnight,'' said the statement, which was signed P. O'Neill, the pseudonym for the IRA army council. ``Our active service units reserve the right to take defensive actions,'' it added. In his comments, Brooke said: ``A cease-fire in Northern Ireland, albeit brief, is a welcome epitaph to 1990 and maybe a pointer to achieving a lasting solution in 1991.'' ``There could ... be no better news on the eve of the New Year than that the message that terrorism cannot be allowed to succeed may have taken root, and that recognition has dawned that there is no future for terrorism,'' he said. In Northern Ireland, lawmaker Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, said, ``The IRA calling cease-fires has nothing whatsoever to do with the community interest, but is to give themselves the opportunity to reorganize and re-stock. It should be viewed in that light.'' Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said he ``earnestly hoped'' the move could be extended indefinitely - a development he said would ``open up great possibilities for progress.'' The last suspension of the IRA's 20-year-old battle to drive the British out of Northern Ireland was in December 1974 and lasted eight months. Since the largely Roman Catholic IRA began its guerrilla fight, 2,849 people have been killed in violence. The struggle pits Catholic nationalists against Protestant loyalists determined to retain the predominantly Protestant province's link to Britain. The IRA wants to unite the province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic. ``The leadership of the IRA extends greetings to all those who suffered as a result of the British-occupied six Irish counties,'' the IRA statement said. ``We are particularly mindful of all the families who have been bereaved in the last 20 years and of the political prisoners and their families.'' Gerry Adams, president of the the IRA's legal political wing Sinn Fein, said of the cease-fire, ``I welcome the news and hope that the British forces will respond in kind so that Irish people can have a peaceful Christmas.''

DOC.HEAD: Cyclone, Bushfires In Australia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with new injuries reported, bushfire damage, other; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A cyclone off Queensland state, bushfires in New South Wales and severe thunderstorms in Victoria state combined to batter the east coast of Australia over the weekend. Temperatures ranging as high as 113 degrees and gusty winds in dry conditions fueled fires around Sydney and in other parts of New South Wales state on Sunday. At least five people were injured in the fires, including two firefighters. Thousands of residents were forced to flee their homes as up to 370 fires burned around the city in the worst day of bushfires in more than 20 years, emergency officials said. More than 500 bushfires were burning late Sunday night in the state, but most were under control. At least 20 houses were destroyed, including 13 at Gosford north of Sydney. Officials said some of the fires may have been deliberately set. On the far north Queensland coast, residents were preparing for Cyclone Joy, a tropical storm that forecasters are rating as powerful as Cyclone Tracy, which claimed 50 lives when it hit Darwin in the Northern Territory on Christmas Day in 1974. Cyclone Joy was off the coast Sunday night and expected to start moving towards the coast later. High winds associated with the storm have already cut power supplies in the tourist city of Cairns, where the international airport was closed. On the southeast coast, a freak thunderstorm Saturday night brought down power lines in Melbourne, Victoria's capital. There were several injuries reported from fallen trees, none of them serious.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Interior Minister Sues Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Aryeh Deri said he sued a leading Israeli daily for libel on Sunday for suggesting he may have exploited his position to purchase four apartments. The article, which was published by the Yedioth Ahronoth daily six months ago, preceded the opening of a police investigation of Deri and his aides on suspicion of fraud and mishandling public funds. Deri's ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians faction is a key member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's governing coalition, which relies heavily on smaller religious parties for majority support in the 120-member Parliament. In the suit filed in Tel Aviv District Court, Deri, 31, asked for $500,000 in damage, state radio and television said. ``The moment Yedioth hinted, and quite heavily, that I exploited my status or state resources to achieve the many assets I acquired, this I will not pass over lightly,'' Deri said on TV. On radio, Deri said, ``This is the first libel suit, others are on the way. I will fight until the end ... to put things in place and expose my truth.'' Yedioth Ahronoth editor Moshe Vardi responded in a statement read to reporters, ``If anyone thinks that this is the way to quiet the press, he will learn it is a mistake, and on the matter of the facts, this the court will decide.'' The newspaper is one of Israel's most widely read dailies. It has not yet filed a defense statement with the court, the national Itim news agency reported. No trial date was immediately set. According to the radio and Itim, the article in question was published by Yedioth on June 15. It reportedly suggested that Deri and his wife owned four luxury apartments, and said the ``minister's salary is insufficient to fund the purchase of this property.'' Deri has denied ownership of at least two of the apartments, the reports added. Another article published by Yedioth in June accused Deri of unlawfully funneling hundreds of thousands of shekels to public councils and religious institutions that supported his party. A shekel is worth about 50 cents. Police later opened an investigation into these suspicions, and some in Deri's party later threatened to bolt Shamir's coalition unless the inquiry was dropped. Deri said Sunday he learned that the investigation was ``reaching its conclusion.'' He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait-Based Palestinians Allowed Rights To Sponsor
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians registered as residents of Kuwait have been given the right to sponsor foreign nationals who want to stay in the occupied emirate, travelers said Sunday. Indians who fled Kuwait through Dubai en route home, speaking on condition of anonymity, said thousands of Indians have acquired the new Iraqi documents allowing them to stay in Kuwait, which Iraq calls its 19th province. Members of the large expatriate population working in oil-rich countries in the area can acquire residence permits only if they are sponsored by local citizens, companies or government departments. The sources said the Palestinians have been given the status of a ``first class'' resident with the right to sponsor other foreigners. Until Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Palestinians themselves were under the sponsorship of Kuwaiti nationals. The sources said the Palestinians stood by Iraq after it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and now apparently have been rewarded. Kuwaiti exiles have accused Iraq of trying to repopulate their country with Palestinians, Iraqis and others sympathetic to the occupation.

DOC.HEAD: 30 More Dead in Government Offensive in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: At least 30 more soldiers and Tamil rebels were killed on the third day of a government offensive, military officials said Sunday. The bullet-riddled bodies of more than 50 Tamils, most of them women, were found in two villages and in a lagoon in curfew-bound Batticaloa, 135 miles east of Colombo, villagers said. But it was unknown who killed the victims. In the offensive, government planes pounded a rebel camp at Telipillai in the Jaffna eninsula on Saturday, killing 17 rebels, the officials said. The Tamil Tiger rebels later killed nine soldiers during the army's attempt to overrun the camp, according to the military officials, who cannot be quoted under briefing rules. The Jaffna Peninsula, 185 miles northeast of Colombo, is the Tigers' biggest stronghold. The rebels killed four other soldiers, including a captain, in an ambush Saturday at Weli Oya in the Trincomalee district, about 140 miles northeast of Colombo. Villagers contacted by telephone said on condition of anonymity that 15 of the bullet-riddled Tamil bodies were found in Kurumanvelli, south of Batticaloa, and 17 at Kirankulam in the west. They said at least 20 bodies, 15 of them female, were seen floating in the Batticaloa lagoon. Military officials said they knew nothing about the bodies but would investigate the reports. The government's newest offensive in the 7{-year-old war with the Tamil guerrillas followed Wednesday's killing of Brig. Lucky Wijeratne. Wijeratne, whose jeep was blown up by a land mine, was the most senior officer killed in the revolt against the country's Sinhalese majority. The latest deaths brought the toll in the offensive to 131 rebels and 24 government troops, according to government tallies. The Tigers, who seldom release casualty tolls, have issued no statements on the latest fighting. More than 14,000 people have died since Tamil militants started fighting in 1983 for a separate homeland for their ethnic minority. Tamils make up 18 percent of the 16 million people in Sri Lanka, an island off the southern tip of India. They have long accused the Sinhalese of discrimination in jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language. Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population, control the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SHELDON, Mich.
Father, Six Children Die in House Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Fire Capt. ...' to locate fire; Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Paulun said ...'
DOC.TEXT: A father and six of his nine children died in a fire that started when the family's Christmas tree ignited in their suburban Detroit home, authorities said Sunday. Martin Dellorco and six children between the ages of 4 and 12 were killed in the fire in Wayne County's Canton Township late Saturday, said Fire Chief Melvin Paulun. Dellorco, 38, escaped at first and then was killed when he returned to the house in a vain attempt to save the children, authorities said. Fire Capt. Art Winkel said the fire, which apparently started when the Christmas tree fell over in the family room, spread quickly through the one-story home in the township 22 miles west of Detroit. It was unknown how the tree fell or how the fire was sparked after the fall, Winkel said. Paulun said Dellorco's wife, Debbie, 36, and their son Adam, 6, escaped. Mrs. Dellorco was treated and released at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, hospital spokeswoman Margaret Kirkby said Sunday. Adam did not require hospital treatment. Paulun identified the Dellorco children killed as Bonnie, 12; Sara, 9; Katie, 8; twins Megan and Michael, 5; and Robert, 4. He said the bodies were found throughout the house. Dellorco escaped and then ``re-entered to save his children,'' Paulun said. ``He was not successful and he died as a result.'' The Dellorcos' two teen-age children - Jimmy, 16, and Kelly, 14 - weren't at home when the fire started. ``They wanted a big family. Someone was saying they wanted 13 or 14 kids,'' Chris Ruszkiewicz, 17, a neighbor and schoolmate of Jimmy Dellorco at Plymouth-Canton High School, said Sunday. ``This is just awful.'' Paulun said fire teams found the ranch-style house engulfed by flames when they arrived about 11:15 p.m. He said intense heat blocked firefighters from entering the house, and one firefighter suffered minor burns. ``It was just something you can't describe,'' said neighbor Dawn Ross, 18. The fire was under control about midnight, Paulun said. He said investigators were continuing their probe Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Fire on Buses in Kashmir, Kill Five
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers fired on two buses in the Kashmir Valley, fatally wounding at least five passengers, police and witnesses said Sunday. They said about 10 others suffered lesser wounds. No immediate explanation surfaced for the shooting Saturday, but the witnesses said Moslem militants attacked army troops in the same area the previous day. One soldier was killed in Friday's attack, according to sources. The buses were fired Saturday on about six miles west of Srinagar on the road linking Baramulla and Uri, police in Srinagar and residents of the area said. All sources spoke on condition of anonymity. Police and residents said three people died at the scene. Two more people died Sunday of their wounds, the residents said. Srinagar newspapers reported eight people were killed, but there was no confirmation. At least 1,692 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20, when India launched a crackdown on an increasingly violent secessionist movement by Moslems. Kashmir is part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only Indian state with a Moslem majority.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Die in Spain in Van-School Bus Collision
DOC.TEXT: A van carrying eight Moroccans swerved head-on into a bus filled with vacationing schoolchildren on a foggy road, killing 10 people, police said Sunday. A civil guard said all eight Moroccans died in the crash Saturday on the N-331 highway in southern Malaga province. He said the 58-year-old Spanish bus driver and his son, 28, were also killed and three schoolchildren were injured, one seriously. The bus was taking the children from Malaga to an excursion in the nearby mountains. The Moroccans were believed to be heading home from their jobs in France, said the guard, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Escape From Alcatraz: Nearly 30 Years Later, Escapees Still Sought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `That interest ...' to delete extraneous word, `aired'; Picks up 10th graf, `A woman ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: Nearly three decades after three inmates broke out of the island prison of Alcatraz, debate persists over whether they made it across San Francisco Bay to achieve the only successful escape from ``The Rock.'' Many believe the men drowned in the bay's cold waters. But as recently as two weeks ago, officials in Florida were still looking for brothers Clarence and John Anglin and their companion Frank Lee Morris, the San Francisco Daily Journal said in a report to be published Monday. ``What we're looking at is the possibility that two of the three escapees, the Anglin brothers, who were raised in this vicinity, possibly escaped and came back to this area,'' U.S. Marshal W.L. ``Mac'' McLendon in Tallahassee, Fla., told the newspaper, a daily that covers legal matters. Officials began looking for the Anglin brothers in the northwest Florida area about two years ago and recently confirmed the search was continuing. At least 41 known escape attempts were made at the prison from 1934 until it closed in 1963. But none of the would-be escapees - with the possible exception of the Anglins and Morris - succeeded. The prison, which housed notorious criminals such as Al Capone, George ``Machine Gun'' Kelly and ``Birdman'' Robert Stroud, is now part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area and a popular tourist attraction. In San Francisco, Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal Richard Bippus would only confirm that interest in the case was high. ``It's like a roller coaster,'' Bippus said. ``It goes uphill and downhill. We're on an uphill right now. Our interest is more active, let's say.'' That interest was revived in 1989, when a segment about the June 11, 1962, escape was broadcast on the NBC-TV program ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' A woman who identified herself only as Cathy called the show's tip number and said she recognized Clarence Anglin as a man who lived on a farm near Marianna, Fla., McLendon said. The brothers also were linked to the area by a woman, who recognized a photo of Clarence Anglin and said he lived near Marianna. She correctly identified his eye color, height and other physical features. Another witness identified a sketch of Morris, saying it bore a striking resemblance to a man she had seen in the area. In 1986, Clarence Anglin's grandson claimed his grandfather had died a free man in Iowa more than a decade after the escape and that the other two men were eaten by sharks during the escape attempt. The breakout from the institution, which prided itself as being escape-proof, embarrassed prison authorities. The men first broke through barred air vents at the back of their cells, giving them access to an interior utility corridor separating the two halves of the three-tiered block of cells. All three were housed on the ground floor. In that area, they spent months making things for their escape, including life vests and at least one rubber raft, apparently using pilfered raincoats. The night of their escape, they put dummies in their beds, broke through the vents, scaled pipes to the roof, and dropped to the waters below. Authorities believe they then inflated a raft or rafts and launched them on chilly waters. Two life vests, a wooden paddle and a packet with pictures and addresses belonging to the inmates later were found floating in the bay. Some believe the men drowned trying to make the two-mile crossing. But others, including Bippus, believe the items were planted to throw officials off track. ``It would be nice if the Anglin brothers would turn themselves in and we could get rid of this - and they could stop looking over their shoulders,'' Bippus said.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Arrested After Daughter of Multimillionaire Ransomed
DOC.TEXT: Seven people were arrested in the kidnapping of the daughter of a Vancouver multimillionaire who was freed after a ransom was paid, authorities said Sunday. Few details were released about the abduction of 30-year-old Cynthia Kilburn, who was kidnapped from her home in this Vancouver suburb Friday morning and freed 14 hours later on Saturday. Police did not disclose the ransom amount. Mrs. Kilburn was shaken, but otherwise unharmed during the ordeal, Royal Canadian Mounted Police in North Vancouver said. Her 4-year-old twins, a boy and a girl who were bound and left at the home, also apparently were unharmed even though they were left alone most of the day. ``We're fine,'' Mrs. Kilburn's husband, Alan, said Saturday night. ``It was pretty tense but we're fine.'' Mrs. Kilburn is the daughter of Jim Pattison, who was chairman of the Expo '86 World's Fair in Vancouver. His conglomerate, Jim Pattison Group, owns several auto dealerships, a supermarket chain and radio stations. Three men and four juveniles, including a girl, were arrested late Saturday and early Sunday at various locations, police Sgt. Bill Sharp said. Their names were withheld. ``We're very grateful to the Lord that everything turned out all right,'' Pattison said after his blindfolded daughter had been dropped off on a north Vancouver street corner. ``These kinds of things make you aware that the world has got some circumstances that you have to be aware of.''

DOC.HEAD: Roads Icy As Record Cold Continues, Deaths Reach 60
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS overline to conform to 0 deaths in text
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dropped as low as 39 degrees below zero Sunday as the arctic cold wave refrigerated the western two-thirds of the nation and edged toward the East with freezing rain and ice that sent cars and trucks sliding. At the same time, record highs in the 60s and 70s extended from New England to Georgia. Flooding forced the evacuation of hundreds of people in parts of Kentucky, Tennessee and Alabama, where nearly a foot of rain had fallen. At least 60 deaths had been blamed on the weather since the cold began Tuesday. Most were traffic fatalities but some died of hypothermia or from fires blamed on overworked heaters or fireplaces. Hardest hit was Texas with 19 deaths, 16 in traffic accidents. Many glazed bridges and roadways across the state were covered by ice up to an inch thick Sunday. Ice also spread eastward with the advance of the cold. A combination of snow, sleet and freezing rain fell on Indiana during the night and Sunday morning. An ice storm moved into western Kentucky. Freezing rain also swept across Pennsylvania. The coldest spot in the Lower 48 states was in northwestern Colorado, at Craig, where Sunday's low was 39 degrees below zero, the National Weather Service said. Denver hit a record 16 below. Wyoming's cold spot was Jackson with a reading of 35 below at midmorning and a wind chill of 60 below. Cheyenne was above zero, at 5, but the wind chill was 39 below. Arizona, the magnet for thousands of ``snow birds'' who annually flee colder northern states, did not have one reporting station with a low above freezing Sunday. Phoenix hit a record 26 and Tucson dropped to a record 21. Albuquerque, N.M., dropped to 7 below zero Sunday, the first time on record the city has gone below zero in December. The city that bills itself the ``Ice Box of the Nation,'' International Falls, Minn., took Sunday's low of 29 below in stride. ``It's business as usual - you have no choice up here,'' restaurant owner Chris Mostad said Sunday. The cold air was pressing against a belt of unseasonably warm air along the East Coast, and was expected to overrun the Northeast on Monday. Record highs included 64 at Harrisburg, Pa.; 67 at Newark, N.J.; 65 at Boston; 58 at Burlington, Vt.; 69 at Baltimore; 72 at Atlanta, and 73 at Richmond, Va. At Topsail Island, N.C. ``People are walking around here with shorts and T-shirts on,'' said Kevin Hollis. ``It just doesn't seem like Christmas with this weather,'' said Tom Chroniger, hitting baseballs with a friend at Burtonsville, Md. In California's Central Valley, the cold threatened about 80 percent of the navel orange crop still on trees, said Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual in Visalia. ``Some of the growers I talked to had 14 hours at 26 and below and that's going to cause damage,'' Holland said Sunday. Citrus growers in southern Texas checked their crops for frost damage from below-freezing temperatures, but there was no immediate word on crop loss. ``I've been here in '83 (during a severe freeze) and it's not freezing like that at all,'' said Burt Purvis, who works on a citrus farm near McAllen. Too much water, not ice, caused flooding from southern Indiana across Kentucky and Tennessee into Alabama. In northern Alabama, flooding from nearly 1 foot of rain from Friday night into Sunday chased dozens of residents from their homes Sunday and rescue workers scurried to aid motorists stranded on submerged roads. ``We can't turn the faucet off,'' said Fred Keeney, a planner with the Morgan County (Ala.) Emergency Management Agency. ``We don't really know how many evacuations. ... We've got a lot of people who have been moved.'' Flooding in southeastern Tennessee forced more than 450 people from their homes and 600 were isolated with roads under water and some bridges washed out, authorities said. The Tennessee Valley Authority was releasing water from all of its dams after up to 5 inches of rain fell in the region overnight. Dozens of people were evacuated in southeastern Kentucky as streams rose after days of saturating rain. Since Dec. 16, Bell County has received 6.6 inches of rain, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainer Correctly Predicts 2-2-2 - But Didn't Buy Lottery Ticket
DOC.TEXT: Psychic entertainer Jim Karol began closing his shows about a month ago with a tip: Play 2-2-2 in the Pennsylvania Daily Number drawing on Dec. 22. ``Something just told me to do it,'' he said. When the numbers 2-2-2 came up Saturday night, Karol was happy that those who followed prediction made a little extra money. He's just sorry he wasn't among them. ``That's the part that stinks,'' he said. Karol performs on about 100 college campuses each year, at dozens of charity benefits, company Christmas parties, and fire company socials. He performed at the White House during last year's annual Easter Egg Roll. He made his lottery prediction over and over - at the Germansville Fire Company, before members of the Lehigh Valley Traffic Club, to a Parents Without Partners support group and hotel employees. ``I must have said that at at least 45 shows,'' Karol said. ``I came in contact with literally thousands of people.'' After watching Karol perform at the volunteer fire company hall in Lehigh Township, Kenneth Hantz bought 2-2-2 tickets for Saturday. Now, he's $1,000 richer. The number was popular statewide. Lottery officials said there were 39,863 winning tickets - resulting in a payout of $13,883,700. ``I made so many people money tonight,'' Karol said. ``It's a Christmas present for all the people.''

DOC.HEAD: Iran Merges Navy, Revolutionary Guards Naval Forces
DOC.TEXT: Iran's two naval forces were merged Sunday in a move to streamline the chain of command and wipe out overlapping functions. Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said the merged naval forces of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and the regular navy will be commanded by Rear Adm. Ali Shamkhani, now chief of the navy. President Hashemi Rafsanjani had been trying to merge the two forces since his election in July 1989, but had to move slowly because the merger was opposed by the powerful Revolutionary Guards. The merger is believed to be a big step toward a full merger of the military and air force as well.

DOC.HEAD: English, Welsh Stores Defy Law, Open on Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of stores in England and Wales opened in defiance of trading laws Sunday, taking advantage of one of the last two shopping days before Christmas. The open violations of the law, in some cases advertised in the newspapers, followed similar openings last week. For the large stores, drawing thousands of customers, the fines levied against them are not a hardship. Some managers reported ``absolutely fantastic'' business, the shopworkers' union said it wasn't fair to the staffs, and the Keep Sunday Special campaign said people were complaining that the shop openings disrupted family life. The issue of Sunday trading has been controversial for years. Prime Minister John Major said in Parliament last week that the time was approaching for talks to find a compromise. The Keep Sunday Special campaign said it was ``inundated'' with complaints from chain store staff under ``intolerable pressure'' to work on Sundays. But Roger Boaden, director of the Shopping Hours Reform Council, said most shop staff working Sunday were volunteers, many on premium pay rates. The Marks and Spencer chain said it would consider opening stores on Sundays only if it became legal. The chain opened its branches in Scotland, where it is legal. At Hamley's, a big toyshop on London's Regent Street, a spokesman said trading was ``absolutely fantastic. We had approximately 1,000 people waiting outside the store when we opened our doors at 12 o'clock, and it has been non-stop since then.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Armed Smugglers Spur Illegal Cigarette Trade in China
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette smuggling by gangs armed with assault rifles and using high-tech equipment is rapidly spreading along China's southeastern coast, the official China Daily's Business Weekly said Sunday. It said illegal cigarette trade has become the sole source of income in some villages, prompting calls for harsher penalties for smugglers and better equipment for coast guards. The newspaper said some people also recommended improving the quality of Chinese cigarettes to reduce demand for foreign tobacco products. A Beijing tobacco industry official told the paper that smuggling has caused a significant cut in state revenue from tobacco sales, which are tightly controlled by the government. The report said officials estimated that smugglers brought 45 million cartons of cigarettes into China last year. The newspaper said smugglers with AK-47 rifles, bulletproof vests and high-frequency walkie-talkies flourished in many coastal villages. It also said smugglers use satellite navigation devices, but gave no details of the operations. The paper said smokers complain that Chinese cigarettes don't taste as good as foreign brands and are hard to smoke because they have poor filters and the tobacco is loosely packed. ``You've got to keep on drawing on the cheaper, homemade ones until your jaw swells,'' one smoker told the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Families Mourn Deaths of Servicemen Killed in Boat Capsizing
With AM-Gulf-Capsize
DOC.TEXT: The roses and birthday card for his 3-year-old daughter arrived the same weekend naval Airman Larry Clark and 20 fellow servicemen died in a naval accident half a world away. ``If anything happens to me before that day, remember Daddy loves you very much,'' Clark wrote to his daughter, Tiffany, who turned 3 on Sunday. The 21-year-old resident of Decatur, Ga., went on to tell his child how he looked forward to watching her grow up. Clark and others were killed Saturday when their ferry capsized as they returned to the aircraft carrier Saratoga following shore leave near Haifa, Israel. Most of the men were in their early 20s. ``I feel like a part of me left when he left,'' said Raymon Carrington, whose twin brother, Monray C. Carrington was among those killed. ``My heart aches.'' The seaman from the Pittsburgh suburb of North Braddock was 22. Also in mourning Sunday was Annie Jackson, who initially had been sure her son, Timothy Jerome Jackson, wasn't among those killed. Her son had promised her he would call everytime the Saratoga went into port and he went ashore. ``I was sure he was on the ship,'' she said. But Saturday at noon, Navy officers knocked at the door of the family home in Anniston, Ala., to tell her the 20-year-old fire control technician had been killed. It was the second tragedy in two years for the family of Airman Apprentice Christopher B. Brown, 19, of the tiny south Georgia town of Leslie. Brown's brother, Michael, died of leukemia at age 15. In Eminence, Ky., townsfolk mourned the death of Airman Brent A. McCreight, who was well-known in the community as a 6-foot-7-inch former high school basketball star. ``We just loved him here,'' said local resident John Berry, whose son went to school with McCreight, 23. ``He was just like a member of the family. They ran around together all the time, and he worked here for me on the farm.'' Also among the casualties was Randy L. Neel, 19, an airman apprentice from Albuquerque who had wanted to become a news photographer. ``He was all excited about being in Israel for Christmas time,'' said his mother, Colleen Neel. ``It's the worst thing that could happen to you,'' said Sheila Settimi, whose son Jeffrey A. Settimi was killed. The 25-year-old mess management seaman apprentice was a Fort Wayne, Ind., native. ``I feel angry in a sense,'' said Mrs. Settimi, who lives in Hamilton, Ind. ``I don't believe President Bush should have put men and women in this situation. ``And now I've been devastated; our worst fears have come true.''

DOC.HEAD: Firefighter Rescues 4-Year-Old Dangling from 3rd Floor
LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: A 4-month-old child dangled from a third-floor balcony in her father's loosening grip, but a firefighter leaned out and scooped up the child, police said Sunday. ``It was one of the most dramatic things I've ever seen,'' said neighbor Mario Franchini after the rescue Saturday of the infant and her father. Roldolfo Regaldo, 31, had taken to the balcony of an apartment house at about 3:30 p.m. after an argument with his wife, and threatened to jump with the sobbing child, police said. Spanish-speaking officers on the ground tried to talk Regaldo down, while behind a door leading to the balcony other authorities waited for a signal to jump out and restrain him, police said. When Regaldo stood up and moved toward the balcony ledge, officers grabbed hold of him, but the baby started to slip from his hand, police said. Firefighter Ron Pearlman leaned over the railing and grabbed the child. Pearlman also nearly fell, but a police officer held onto him and pulled him and the baby to safety. ``When I went in, officers were holding (Regaldo),'' Pearlman said. ``Next thing I saw was the baby swing up. He still was holding on to her. I felt, I gotta go get the kid. So I reached over the side and grabbed the child's shirt. ``There was a tug-of-war, and I heard the shirt tear, so I grabbed an arm,'' he said. ``Then the father let go, so I put my other arm around her butt and pulled her in.'' After the struggle, Regaldo was arrested for investigation of attempting to murder his daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Chains Raise Ad Revenues by Giving Freebies to Moviegoers
DOC.TEXT: Advertisers looking for ways to get their message to moviegoers are turning away from on-screen pitches and hiring movie theaters to hand out free samples of candy, popcorn and other goodies. United Artists, the largest movie chain with 2,500 screens, handed out PB Max candy bars this month to patrons entering its theaters in Los Angeles. UA also was to give moviegoers in its Dallas theaters free boxes of Smart Foods popcorn. Cineplex Odeon, the second largest chain with 1,690 screens, says it's handing out packs of sugar-free Dentyne chewing gum and samples of men's cologne at the end of the movie, said Howard Lichtman, executive vice president of marketing. ``If someone doesn't like a product, we don't want them leaving it on the floor.'' he explained. Instead of paying for time on screen, companies pay chains fees to hand out their products. Marketing experts believe this is one idea the audience won't reject. ``People love free samples,'' said Susan Small-Weil, a specialist in consumer behavior at New York-based ad agency Warwick, Baker & Fiore. ``In this case, advertising isn't an uninvited guest. It's a welcome guest.'' Both UA and Cineplex hope freebies will boost ad revenue lost earlier this year when Walt Disney Co. and Warner Bros. studios banned on-screen advertising at theaters that show their movies. ``The reduction of on-screen advertising is going to hurt us,'' said Cathy Kasberg, director of promotions and marketing at UA. ``Hopefully, this can give us another avenue for income.'' UA hopes to hand out different products such as soap, pens and frozen yogurt every weekend. Other chains have similar plans.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes Lists Most Profitable Companies
With AM-Forbes-List
DOC.TEXT: Athletic footwear maker LA Gear showed the best longterm profitability of public U.S. companies surveyed by Forbes, the magazine announced Sunday. The Los Angeles-based company averaged an 83.2 percent return on equity - primary earnings per share divided by common shareholders' equity per share - in the past four years, according to Forbes' calculations. In the last 12 months however, LA Gear's return on equity fell to 27.8 percent, the magazine said. St. Louis-based Pulitzer Publishing ranked second with an 80.6 percent average return on equity in the past five years. Atlanta-based chemical maker Georgia Gulf was third with 78.4 average ROE in the past four years. Forbes evaluated the profitability of 1,177 companies in 20 industries for its Jan. 7, 1991 annual report issue. Software maker Microsoft Corp., based in Redmond, Wash., was ranked tops among the largest corporations. Microsoft had an ROE average of 50.4 percent over the past five years, which landed it in 16th place on the general list. To be considered among the largest companies, a firm had to have sales of more than $1 billion and a minimum five-year average return on equity of 22 percent, among other requirements. The median company in Forbes' survey had a five-year average ROE of 14.6 percent, up from 14.3 percent in 1989. The latest 12-month ROE for the firms dropped, however, from 14.4 percent to 12.1 percent. Leading Forbes' list of best-performing stocks was Blockbuster Entertainment. The Fort Lauderdale, Fla.-based video rental company had a five-year average stock price increase of 3,060.5 percent, highest among the 1,078 stocks survey by Forbes. Cyprus Minerals, an Englewood, Colo.-based oil, gas and coal company, had the highest rate of earnings-per-share growth with a three-year average of 147.8 percent. Forbes considers companies with annual revenues of $400 million, or $600 million for banks or electric utilities, for its annual report issue. The only exception is biotechnology, where Forbes waives the minimum. The magazine based its rankings on five-year averages, but there were some exceptions to the rule.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Prices Down An Average of Almost Six Cents
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices across the nation fell an average of nearly 6 cents a gallon over the last two weeks, the biggest drop since the Persian Gulf crisis, according to a survey released Sunday. The average price for all grades of gasoline at full and self-serve stations was 140.27 cents a gallon Friday, a drop of 5.79 cents from Dec. 7, according to oil industry analyst Trilby Lundberg's survey of 13,600 gasoline stations. The average price of regular leaded gasoline at self-serve stations last week was 125.87 cents a gallon, while regular unleaded sold for 128.85 cents and premium unleaded was 144.79. Full-service regular leaded retailed for 152.31 cents a gallon, regular unleaded averaged 153.94 cents and premium unleaded sold for 167.62 cents. The first sign of a decrease since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 was the last two weeks in October when prices dipped an average of .18 cents a gallon.
